compound, G50071

(BMS3–35)

0.002 ±0.001 in. (0.051 ±0.026 mm) 0.004 ±0.002 in. (0.102 ±0.051 mm)

(c) The application temperature for BMS3-23, BMS3-26 Type I and BMS3-29, must be

between 40°F (4°C) and 100°F (38°C).

(d) The application temperature for BMS3-26 Type II must be between 50°F (10°C) and

100°F (38°C).

(e) The application temperature for BMS3-35 must be between 32°F (0°C) and 86°F (30°C).

(f) Spray or brush the BMS3-23 compound to get a continuous coat.

(g) Spray or brush either the BMS3-26, BMS3-29 or BMS3-35 compound to get a bubble

free coat (after it is dry), with a wet or dry thickness as specified in Table 701.

NOTE: When the BMS3-26, BMS3-29 and BMS3-35 compound is not sprayed, shake or

mix the compound before it is used.

(h)

When the compound is applied to parts where it cannot be sprayed or brushed (e.g.

slotted tracks), do the step that follows:

\1) Fill the area with the compound, and then drain the compound which will give a

protective coat.

(i) When BMS3-29 is specified as an optional material to BMS3-23, use the same

specifications as for the BMS3-29.

(j) Use a cloth (cotton wiper, G00034) to remove the puddles of too much of the compound if

the puddles cause a blockage to the drain holes or cross drains.

737-600/700/800/900

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-91

EFFECTIVITY

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryed(k) Make sure that you have a good flow of air in the areas where the corrosion inhibiting

compound was applied, as follows:

NOTE: The air flow times are recommended minimum times. A longer air flow time to get

a satisfactory evaporation is recommended for lower temperatures, high humidity,

and when too much of the compound is applied.

NOTE: You must keep the temperature within the application limits for the material used.

\1) After you apply the BMS3–23 in enclosed areas, apply a good air flow to the area

for a minimum of one hour before you close-up the area.

NOTE: The one hour will let the volatile solvents in the compound to evaporate.

\2) After you apply the BMS3-26, BMS3–29 or the BMS3-35 in enclosed areas, apply a

good air flow to the area for a minimum of four hours before you close-up the area.

\3) Do not remove the masking tape or applicable covers until the corrosion inhibiting

compound has dried sufficiently. This will make sure that the compound will not rub

off or move to another surface.

a) When the masking tape or covers have been removed, do a touch-up of the

corrosion inhibiting compound where it is necessary to prevent corrosion in the

areas of a structural interface.

(l) Do not contaminate the insulation blankets with the corrosion inhibiting compound.

NOTE: These compounds can decrease the ability of the insulation blankets to repel

water.

WARNING

DO NOT USE DETERGENTS OR SOLVENTS TO CLEAN THE

INSULATION BLANKET. IT CAN REMOVE FLAME RETARDANTS

AND CAUSE FLAMMABLE RESIDUES ON THE INSULATION

BLANKET WHICH INCREASES THE RISK OF FIRE. THIS CAN

CAUSE INJURIES TO PERSONNEL, AND DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.

\1) If contamination occurs, the blanket must be replaced.

END OF TASK

TASK 51-21-91-620-803

4.

Cure of Corrosion Inhibiting Compound

A. General

(1)

This task to cure the corrosion inhibiting compound is not necessary when the insulation

blankets will not be touched by the compound.

(2) Cure the corrosion inhibiting compound at the specified application temperature.

B. Consumable Materials

Reference

Description

Specification

G00252

Film - Polyethylene Film And Sheeting ASTM D2103

(Supersedes L-P-512)

C. Cure of Corrosion Inhibiting Compound

SUBTASK 51-21-91-620-003

(1) Sufficiently cure the corrosion inhibiting compound.

NOTE: This is to make sure the compound does not move from the surface if it is touched by

the insulation blankets.

(a)

The test that follows will tell you if the compound is fully cured.

in thickness.

\2) Push the polyethylene film, G00252 against the corrosion inhibiting compound with

a light finger pressure.

\3) Make a check to see if the corrosion inhibiting compound has moved to the

polyethylene film, G00252 or lifted from the structure.

(b) The table that follows will give you the approximate cure times.

NOTE: Follow the manufacturers instruction for the applicable cure times.

Table 702/51-21-91-993-802

*[1] BMS3–23 Class 1, will not cure in 1 hour, however, this is a sufficient amount of time to allow solvents to flash off

prior to installation of insulation blankets. BMS3–23 Class 1, does not cure to a tack free coating.

END OF TASK

TASK 51-21-91-620-804

5.

Repair of Corrosion Inhibiting Compound Coating

A. General

(1)

The limits of the damage or bubbles in the BMS3-23, BMS3-26, BMS3-29 or BMS3-35

corrosion inhibiting compound in the cured coating is as follows and must be repaired:

(a) The coating damage dimension is more than 1 percent of a given 1 ft2 (929 cm2 ).

(b) The coating damage dimension is larger than 1 in2 (6 cm2 ).

(2) All damage or bubbles in the cured BMS3–23, BMS3-26, BMS3-29 and BMS3-35 coating must

be repaired.

NOTE: When BMS3-29 or BMS3-35 is specified as optional to BMS3-23, the damage

permitted will be the same as that necessary for the BMS3-23.

B.

Consumable Materials

3

C. Procedure

SUBTASK 51-21-91-620-004

(1) Do the steps that follow to repair the damaged or contaminated corrosion inhibiting compound.

(a) Clean the damaged area with solvent, B00316 or Limonene solvent, B00634.

entry.title: BOEING章节号51-21-81
entry.content:
737-600/700/800/900 AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

ABRASION-RESISTANT TEFLON FINISH - CLEANING/PAINTING

1. General

A. This procedure contains several tasks as follows:

(1)

Preparation of the surface to be finished.

(2) Application of the BMS 10-86 Type I Coating.

(3) Application of the BMS 10-86 Type II Coating.

(4) Application of the BMS 10-86 Type III Coating.

TASK 51-21-81-100-801

C. Procedure

SUBTASK 51-21-81-120-002

(1) Prepare the Surface to be Finished.

WARNING

DO NOT GET SOLVENTS IN YOUR MOUTH, YOUR EYES, OR ON YOUR

SKIN. DO NOT BREATHE THE FUMES FROM SOLVENTS. SOLVENTS

ARE DANGEROUS MATERIALS. SOLVENTS CAN BE FLAMMABLE.

OBEY THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS (MSDS) FOR SOLVENTS.

OBEY LOCAL REGULATIONS FOR THE CORRECT PROCEDURES TO

USE OR DISCARD SOLVENTS. SOLVENTS CAN CAUSE INJURIES TO

PERSONNEL AND DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.

(a) Clean the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034 that is moist with one of the solvents

as follows:

\1) alcohol, B00068

\2) alcohol, B00130

\3) solvent, B00666

(b) Dry the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034 before the solvent dries.

CAUTION

ONLY USE APPROVED SCRAPERS ON THE AIRPLANE SKIN.

SCRAPERS THAT ARE NOT APPROVED CAN MAKE SCRATCHES ON

THE SKIN, AND CAUSE FATIGUE CRACKS.

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryed**(CAUTION PRECEDES)**

CAUTION

DO NOT USE ABRASIVE PADS (SCOTCH-BRITE), OR ABRASIVE PAPER

ON THE ALUMINUM SURFACE UNLESS THE SCRIBE LINE

INSPECTIONS WERE MADE. ABRASIVE PADS CAN SMOOTH THE

ALUMINUM SURFACE AND HIDE THE SCRIBE LINE MARKS. IF YOU

USE ABRASIVE PADS TO REMOVE THE PAINT OR PRIMER BEFORE

YOU DO THE SCRIBE LINE INSPECTIONS, YOU CAN BE REQUIRED TO

DO REPEAT INSPECTIONS BASED ON THE SCRIBE LINE INSPECTION

SERVICE BULLETIN.

(c) Remove all unwanted material from the surface. Use an approved sealant removal tool,

COM-2481 with sealant removal tool handle, COM-4746 to clean around fasteners,

seams, and lap joints.

NOTE: If you use abrasive pads before you do scribe line inspections, you can be

required to do repeat inspections based on the scribe line inspections Service

Bulletin 737-53A1289.

NOTE: An abrasive mat, G00251 or abrasive cloth, B00102 may be used instead of the

scraper.

(d)

Clean the surface again with a cotton wiper, G00034 that is moist with the solvent.

(e) Dry the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034 before the solvent dries.

END OF TASK

entry.title: BOEING章节号51-21-73
entry.content:
737-600/700/800/900 AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

TOPCOAT - CLEANING/PAINTING

1. General

A. This procedure has instructions for the following.

(1)

BMS10-72 Topcoat Application

(2) BMS10-60 Topcoat Application

(3) BMS10-11 Topcoat Application

(4) Chemical Reactivator Application

TASK 51-21-73-370-801

2. BMS10-72 Topcoat Application

A. General

(1)

This task has steps to do the following.

(a) Prepare to apply BMS10-72 topcoat

(b) Apply BMS10-72 topcoat

(2) Boeing recommends you apply the BMS10-72 topcoat when the ambient air temperature is

between 65°F (18°C) and 95°F (35°C).

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if you will apply the paint outside the

recommended temperature range.

(3) Boeing recommends you apply the BMS10-72 topcoat when the relative humidity is less than

70%.

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if you will apply the paint when the relative

humidity is greater than 70%.

B. References

Reference

Title

51-21-72-370-803

BMS10-72 Primer - Application (P/B 701)

E. Prepare to Apply the BMS10-72 Topcoat

SUBTASK 51-21-73-950-006

(1) Mask the surface adjacent to the area you will apply topcoat.

(a) Attach the tags that follow to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\1) “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447

\2) “STATIC PORTS COVERED” tag, G02444

\3) A red tag labeled “AOA SENSORS COVERED”

(b) Put a pitot probe cover, COM-1503 on the pitot probe.

(c) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270 on the static ports.

(d) Do the steps that follow to cover the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

\1) Cover the angle-of-attack sensors with PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape.

a) Apply PG-777 over the blade, plate, and blade-to-plate gap.

NOTE: This is to allow easier removal of 3M 425 aluminum tape.

\2) Cover the PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape with 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape,

G00291.

a)

Shingle the aluminum foil tape from the blade-to-plate gap up to the blade tip

until all of the masking tape is covered.

(3)

Use one of the methods that follow to prepare the surface (TABLE).

(a) Method 1

\1) If there is no surface contamination and the primer will be applied immediately, no

surface preparation is necessary.

\2) If there is surface contamination, solvent clean the surface.

a) Use a wiper, G50262 or one of the abrasives that follow wet with Series 85

solvent, B01005.

<1> Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

<2> Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

<3> Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum

oxide

\3) Immediately wipe the surface dry with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

a) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(b) Method 2

\1) Solvent clean the surface.

a) Use a wiper, G50262 or one of the abrasives that follow wet with Series 85

solvent, B01005.

<1> Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

<2> Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

<3> Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum

oxide

\2) Immediately wipe the surface dry with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

a) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

\3) Sand the surface.

a) Start sanding with one of the abrasives that follow.

<1> Aluminum oxide/zirconium oxide abrasive paper, stearate-free, 100-grit

to 220-grit

<2> Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220, 100-grit to 220-grit

<3> Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide, 100-grit to

220-grit

<4> Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum

oxide, 100-grit to 220-grit

b) Finish sanding with one of the abrasives that follow.

<1> Aluminum oxide/zirconium oxide abrasive paper, stearate-free, 220-grit

or finer

<2> Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220, 220-grit or finer

<3> Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide, 220-grit or

finer

<4> Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum

oxide, 220-grit or finer

\4) Solvent clean the surface to remove sanding dust.

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryed*[5] CA8000C1 or CA8000C2 may be substituted for CA8000C for accelerated curing. The thinner blend in the paint mix

must not contain both CA8000C1 and CA8000C2 at the same time. Use of thinners containing CA8000C1 or

CA8000C2 thinner may only be used on areas where the reduced wet edge and time between coats does not

adversely affect the final appearance of the topcoat, including but not limited to rotation areas, speed stripers, door

bands, and outdoor work areas.

*[6] CA8000C4 or CA8000C5 may be substituted 1:1 for CA8000C for accelerated curing. CA8000C4 or CA8000C5 may

only be used for outdoor touch-up or repair. CA8000C4 and CA8000C5 may not be used if the outside air

temperature is warmer than 60°F (16°C).

*[7] TR-111, TR-112, TR-113, or TR-128 may be substituted for TR-109 for accelerated curing. The thinner blend in the

paint mix must not simultaneously contain some combination of TR-111, TR-112, TR-113, and TR-128. Thinners

containing TR-111, TR-112, TR-113, or TR-128 thinner may only be used on areas where the reduced wet edge and

time between coats does not adversely affect the final appearance of the topcoat, including but not limited to rotation

areas, speed stripes, door bands, and outdoor work areas.

*[8] Paint mixed with TR-128 may be heat cured at 90°F (32°C) for 4 hours if subsequent colors are to be applied over the

base coat.

*[9] TR-109 may be blended with TR-112 to achieve a 4-6 hour cure at 90°F (32°C).

*[10] TR-141 alternate thinner may be substituted 1:1 for TR-109 standard thinner. It is intended to increase wet edge time

when the ambient air temperature is 85°F (29°C) to 100°F (38°C).

TEMPERATURE (F)TASK 51-21-73-370-803

3.

BMS10-60 Topcoat Application

A. General

(1)

This procedure has steps for the following.

(a) Prepare the surface

(b) Apply BMS10-60

(2) Boeing recommends that you apply the BMS10-60 topcoat when the outside air temperature is

between 65°F (18°C) and 95°F (35°C).

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if you will apply the paint outside the

recommended temperature range.

(3) Boeing recommends you apply the BMS10-60 topcoat when the relative humidity is less than

70%.

(a) If the relative humidity is more than 70%, you can force cure the coating at temperatures

between 120°F (49°C) and 160°F (71°C).

B. Tools/Equipment

NOTE: When more than one tool part number is listed under the same “Reference” number, the

tools shown are alternates to each other within the same airplane series. Tool part numbers

that are replaced or non-procurable are preceded by “Opt:”, which stands for Optional.

D. Prepare the Surface

SUBTASK 51-21-73-950-004

(1) Mask the surface adjacent to the area you will apply topcoat.

(a) Attach the tags that follow to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\1) “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447

\2) “STATIC PORTS COVERED” tag, G02444

\3) A red tag labeled “AOA SENSORS COVERED”

(b) Put a pitot probe cover, COM-1503 on the pitot probe.

(c) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270 on the static ports.

(d) Do the steps that follow to cover the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

\1) Cover the angle-of-attack sensors with PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape.

a) Apply PG-777 over the blade, plate, and blade-to-plate gap.

NOTE: This is to allow easier removal of 3M 425 aluminum tape.

\2) Cover the PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape with 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape,

G00291.

a)

Shingle the aluminum foil tape from the blade-to-plate gap up to the blade tip

until all of the masking tape is covered.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-020

(2) Determine the method you will use to prepare the surface (TABLE, Table 705).

(3) Prepare the surface with one of the methods that follow:

(a) Method 1

\1) Solvent clean the surface using a wiper, G50262 or one of the abrasives that follow

wet with Series 85 solvent, B01005.

a) Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

b) Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

c) Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum oxide

\2) Immediately wipe the surface dry with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

a) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

\3) Sand the surface with one of the abrasives that follow.

a) 220-grit or finer sandpaper, G50260

b) 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077

c) Aluminum oxide abrasive paper, very fine

d) Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

e) Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

\4) Solvent clean the surface using a wiper, G50262 wet with Series 85 solvent,

B01005.

\5) Immediately wipe the surface dry with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

a) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

\6) Repeat the solvent cleaning, if necessary.

(b) Method 2

\1) Solvent clean the surface using a wiper, G50262 or one of the abrasives that follow

wet with Series 85 solvent, B01005.

a) Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

b) Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

c) Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum oxide

\2) Sand the surface with one of the abrasives that follow.

a) 220-grit or finer sandpaper, G50260

b) 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077

c) Aluminum oxide abrasive paper, very fine

d) Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

e) Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

\3) Solvent clean the surface using a wiper, G50262 wet with Series 85 solvent,

B01005.

\4) Immediately wipe the surface dry with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

E. Apply the BMS10-60 Topcoat

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-013

(1) Mix the BMS10-60, Type I coating, C00032 or Type II, coating, C00033 using the

manufacturer’s instructions.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-950-002

(2) Mask the areas adjacent to the area where you will apply BMS10-60.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-016

(3) To spray apply the BMS10-60, do the steps that follow.

(a) Use one of the tools that follow to spray-apply the enamel coating.

\1) Air gun

\2) Airless gun

\3) Air-assisted airless gun

\4) High volume low pressure (HVLP) gun

(b) Spray each single coat by cross-coating.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-017

(4) To brush apply the BMS10-60, do the steps that follow.

(a) Apply the coating using a natural bristle paint brush.

(b) Apply the coating in one direction.

(c) Apply the coating with light pressure on the brush.

(d) Make sure that the coating is applied in an even, continuous coat.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-018

(5) Cure the BMS10-60 topcoat using the steps that follow.

(a) Make sure that the maximum temperature of the coating is less than 250°F (121°C).

(b) For curing before service, see Table 707.

4.

BMS10-11 Topcoat Application

A. General

(1)

This task gives instructions to do the following.

(a) Prepare to Apply the BMS10-11 Topcoat

(b) Apply the BMS10-11 Topcoat

(2) Boeing recommends that you apply the BMS10-11 chemical-resistant and solvent-resistant

finish when the finish temperature is warmer than 50°F (10°C).

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if the finish temperature is colder than 50°F

(10°C).

(3) Boeing recommends that you apply the BMS10-11 chemical-resistant and solvent-resistant

finish when the relative humidity is less than 85%.

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if the relative humidity is more than 85%.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-950-005

(1) Mask the surface adjacent to the area you will apply topcoat.

(a) Attach the tags that follow to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\2) “STATIC PORTS COVERED” tag, G02444

(b) Put a pitot probe cover, COM-1503 on the pitot probe.

(c) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270 on the static ports.

(d) Do the steps that follow to cover the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-028

(3) Use one of the methods that follow to prepare the surface.

(a) Method 1

\1) Solvent clean the surface.

\2) Sand the surface with 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077, if necessary to

clean the surface.

\3) Solvent clean the surface to remove sanding dust.

(b) Method 2

\1) Solvent clean the surface.

\2) Sand the surface with one of the abrasives that follow.

a) Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum oxide

b) Scotch-Brite General Purpose Hand Pad 7447, very fine, aluminum oxide

c) Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

d) 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077

e) Make sure that you do not sand the substrate.

\3) Solvent clean the surface to remove sanding dust.

\4) Use compressed air or a tack rag, G50123 to remove sanding dust, if necessary.

(c) Method 3

\1) Solvent clean the surface.

a) Use a Scotch-Brite General Purpose Hand Pad 7447 (very fine, aluminum

oxide) or a Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish (very fine, aluminum oxide), if

necessary.

\2) Alkaline clean the surface.

a) Use a Scotch-Brite General Purpose Hand Pad 7447 (very fine, aluminum

oxide) or a Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish (very fine, aluminum oxide) wet with

alkaline cleaner that is diluted with three parts of water, by volume.

\3) Rinse the surface with large amounts of water.

\4) Do a check for a water-break-free surface.

a) If water breaks occur, alkaline clean the surface again and rinse with more

water.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-022

(4) Mix the BMS10-11 coating, C00260 using the manufacturer’s instructions.

E. Apply the BMS10-11 Topcoat

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-023

(1) Immediately before you apply the BMS10-11 topcoat, use a tack rag, G50123 to remove loose

dust and lint.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-024

(2) Spray or brush apply the BMS10-11 coating, C00260.

(a) Apply the finish in a continuous coat.

(b) Make sure that the coat is free of solids, runs, sags, fish eyes, blisters, and non-adherent

overspray.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-025

(3) Cure the topcoat.

(a) See Table 711 and Figure 705 to cure the primer.

5.

Chemical Reactivator Application

A. General

(1)

This procedure has steps for the following.

(a) Prepare to apply the Sur-Prep AP-1 chemical reactivator.

(b) Apply the Sur-Prep AP-1 chemical reactivator.

(2) Boeing recommends that you apply Sur-Prep AP-1 when the ambient air temperature is

between 65°F (18°C) and 90°F (32°C).

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if you will apply Sur-Prep AP-1 outside the

recommended temperature range.

(3) Boeing recommends that you apply Sur-Prep AP-1 when the relative humidity is less than

70%.

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if you will apply Sur-Prep AP-1 when the

relative humidity is more than 70%.

(4) Do not apply Sur-Prep AP-1 when the relative humidity at the application temperature is below

that in Figure 706.

B. Tools/Equipment

NOTE: When more than one tool part number is listed under the same “Reference” number, the

tools shown are alternates to each other within the same airplane series. Tool part numbers

that are replaced or non-procurable are preceded by “Opt:”, which stands for Optional.

D. Prepare to Apply the Sur-Prep AP-1 Chemical Reactivator

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-007

(1) Mix the Sur-Prep AP-1 using the manufacturer’s instructions.

(a) Make sure that the ambient air temperature is between 65°F (18°C) and 90°F (32°C).

(b) Make sure that no liquid water or moisture mixes with the chemical reactivator.

NOTE: Liquid water or moisture mixed with the chemical reactivator can cause a white

precipitate and can affect the bond between topcoats.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-950-003

(2) Mask the areas that will not be coated with Sur-Prep AP-1.

(a) Attach the tags that follow to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\1) “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447

\2) “STATIC PORTS COVERED” tag, G02444

\3) A red tag labeled “AOA SENSORS COVERED”

(b) Put a pitot probe cover, COM-1503 on the pitot probe.

(c) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270 on the static ports.

(d) Do the steps that follow to cover the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

\1) Cover the angle-of-attack sensors with PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape.

a) Apply PG-777 over the blade, plate, and blade-to-plate gap.

NOTE: This is to allow easier removal of 3M 425 aluminum tape.

\2) Cover the PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape with 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape,

G00291.

a)

Shingle the aluminum foil tape from the blade-to-plate gap up to the blade tip

until all of the masking tape is covered.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-160-017

(3) If there is surface contamination, do the steps that follow to clean the surface.

(a) Solvent clean the surface.

\1) Use a wiper, G50262 wet with Series 85 solvent, B01005.

\2) Immediately wipe the surface with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

a) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(b) Sand the surface, if necessary to remove contamination.

\1) Use one of the abrasives that follow.

a) Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

b) Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

c) Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum oxide

(c) If you sand the surface, solvent clean the surface to remove sanding dust.

\1) Use a wiper, G50262 wet with Series 85 solvent, B01005.

\2) Immediately wipe the surface with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

737-600/700/800/900

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-73

NoC

Page 732

D633A101-BPA

Oct 15/2022

ECCN 9E991 BOEING PROPRIETARY - See title page for details

EFFECTIVITY

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryeda) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-008

(4) Make sure that the conditions in Figure 706 are met.

E. Apply the Sur-Prep AP-1 Chemical Reactivator

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-009

(1) Spray apply the Sur-Prep AP-1 using one of the tools that follow.

(a) High volume, low pressure (HVLP) gun

(b) Air assisted airless spray gun

(c) Electrostatic spray equipment

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-010

(2) Make sure that all necessary areas are coated with a thin, wet film.

(a) If there is overspray of Sur-Prep AP-1 onto surfaces that do not need to be reactivated

and that have not been masked, do the steps that follow.

\1) Use a wiper, G50262 or one of the abrasives that follow wet with methyl propyl

ketone (MPK) solvent, B00666 or a 70/30 mixture of MPK solvent, B00666/methyl

ethyl ketone (MEK) solvent, B00148.

a) Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

b) Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

c) Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum oxide

\2) Immediately wipe the surface dry with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

a) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-011

(3) Keep the Sur-Prep AP-1 on the surface for 30 minutes to 24 hours in the conditions in

Figure 706 before applying topcoat.

(a) If the Sur-Prep AP-1 is not dry after 30 minutes, let the Sur-Prep AP-1 dry for a longer

time.

SUBTASK 51-21-73-160-018

(4) If the chemical reactivator has runs or if there are very wet areas after you apply the Sur-Prep

AP-1, do the steps that follow.

(a) Dry the defect area with clean, compressed air.

(b) Solvent clean the defect area.

NOTE: This is to remove the dried powder.

\1) Use a wiper, G50262 or one of the abrasives that follow wet with methyl propyl

ketone (MPK) solvent, B00666 or a 70/30 mixture, by volume, of MPK solvent,

B00666/methyl ethyl ketone (MEK) solvent, B00148.

a) Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

b) Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

c) Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum oxide

(c) Re-apply the Sur-Prep AP-1

SUBTASK 51-21-73-370-012

(5) If the Sur-Prep AP-1 is on the surface for more than 24 hours or if there is contamination,

debris, contact with water, or rubbing with materials, do the steps that follow.

Use a wiper, G50262 or one of the abrasives that follow wet with methyl propyl

ketone (MPK) solvent, B00666 or a 70/30 mixture of MPK solvent, B00666/methyl

ethyl ketone (MEK) solvent, B00148.

a) Scotch-Brite 7447 pad, G50220

\2) Immediately wipe the surface dry with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

a) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

\3) Wipe the surface with a tack rag, G50123.

\4) Re-apply the Sur-Prep AP-1.

737-600/700/800/900 AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

PRIMER - CLEANING/PAINTING

1. General

A. This procedure has the tasks below to apply primer.

(1)

BMS10-79, Type II and Type III, Primer - Application

(2) BMS10-103, Type 1, Primer - Application

(3) BMS10-72 Primer - Application

(4) BMS10-11 Primer - Application

TASK 51-21-72-370-801

2. BMS10-79 Primer - Application

A. General

(1)

This procedure has steps to do the following.

(a) Prepare to apply the BMS10-79 Primer

(b) Apply the BMS10-79 Primer

(c) Minor rework

(d) Major rework

(2) Boeing recommends that the ambient air temperature be between 50°F (10°C) and 90°F

(32°C) while applying BMS10-79 primer.

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if you will apply the paint outside the

recommended temperature range.

(a) Remove small amounts of contamination that is oily with the steps that follow.

\1) Use a wiper, G50262 wet with water.

\2) Dry the surface with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

(b) Remove small amounts of oily contamination with the steps that follow.

\1) Solvent clean the surface.

a) Use a wiper, G50262 wet with Series 84 solvent, B01004.

b) Immediately wipe the surface dry with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

<1> Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

SUBTASK 51-21-72-160-010

(a) If the surface becomes contaminated, solvent clean the surface.

\1) Use a wiper, G50262 wet with Series 84 solvent, B01004.

\2) Immediately wipe the surface dry with a clean, dry wiper, G50262.

a) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(4) Prepare surfaces with paint with one of the methods listed in Table 701.

(b) Method 2

\2) Sand the surface to remove gloss with 220-grit or finer sandpaper, G50260,

silicone-free abrasive.

3.

BMS10-103, Type 1, Primer - Application

A. General

(1)

This procedure has steps to do the following.

(a) Prepare to apply the BMS10-103, Type 1, Primer

(b) Apply the BMS10-103, Type 1, Primer

(c) Minor re-work for composite surfaces (substrate exposed)

(d) Minor re-work for titanium and CRES surfaces (substrate exposed)

(e) Major re-work for composite surfaces

(f) Major re-work for titanium and CRES surfaces

(2) Boeing recommends you apply the BMS10-103, Type 1, primer when the ambient air

temperature is between 40°F (4°C) and 100°F (38°C).

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if you will apply the paint outside the

recommended temperature range.

E. Prepare to Apply the BMS10-103, Type 1, Primer

SUBTASK 51-21-72-370-004

(1) Mask all areas that will not be coated with the primer.

(a) Attach the tags that follow to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\1) “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447

\2) “STATIC PORTS COVERED” tag, G02444

\3) A red tag labeled “AOA SENSORS COVERED”

(b) Put a pitot probe cover, COM-1503 on the pitot probe.

(c) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270 on the static ports.

(d) Do the steps that follow to cover the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

\1) Cover the angle-of-attack sensors with PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape.

a) Apply PG-777 over the blade, plate, and blade-to-plate gap.

NOTE: This is to allow easier removal of 3M 425 aluminum tape.

\2) Cover the PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape with 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape,

G00291.

a)

Shingle the aluminum foil tape from the blade-to-plate gap up to the blade tip

until all of the masking tape is covered.

SUBTASK 51-21-72-160-001

(2) For bare exterior composite or plastic surfaces, do the steps that follow.

NOTE: These steps are not applicable to BMS8-267 or BMS8-341, Type II, Form 2, surfaces.

(a) Abrade the surface with 100-grit or finer aluminum oxide, silicone free, abrasive paper or

cloth.

\1)

Use a pneumatic sander to abrade the surface.

(b) Abrade the surface with one of the abrasive pads that follow and a pneumatic sander.

TASK 51-21-72-370-803

4.

BMS10-72 Primer - Application

A. General

(1)

This procedure has steps to do the following:

(a) Prepare to apply BMS10-72 primer.

(b) Apply BMS10-72 primer.

(2) Boeing recommends that you apply BMS10-72 primer when the ambient air temperature is

between 65°F (18°C) and 95°F (35°C).

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if you will apply BMS10-72 primer outside

the recommended temperature range.

(3) Boeing recommends that you apply BMS10-72 primer when the relative humidity is less than

70%.

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if you will apply BMS10-72 primer when the

relative humidity is more than 70%.

D. Prepare to the BMS10-72 Primer Application

SUBTASK 51-21-72-950-002

(1) Mask the surface adjacent to the area you will apply primer.

(a) Attach the tags that follow to the left control wheel in the flight deck:

\1) “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447

\2) “STATIC PORTS COVERED” tag, G02444

\3) A red tag labeled “AOA SENSORS COVERED”.

(b) Put a pitot probe cover, COM-1503, on the pitot probe.

(c) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270, on the static ports.

A. General

(1)

This task gives instructions to do the following.

(a) Prepare to Apply the BMS10-11 Primer

(b) Apply the BMS10-11 Primer

(2) Boeing recommends that you apply the BMS10-11 chemical- and solvent-resistant finish when

the finish temperature is warmer than 50°F (10°C).

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if the finish temperature is colder than 50°F

(10°C).

(3) Boeing recommends that you apply the BMS10-11 chemical- and solvent-resistant finish when

the relative humidity is less than 85%.

(a) Contact the paint manufacturer for guidance if the relative humidity is more than 85%.

B. Tools/Equipment

NOTE: When more than one tool part number is listed under the same “Reference” number, the

tools shown are alternates to each other within the same airplane series. Tool part numbers

that are replaced or non-procurable are preceded by “Opt:”, which stands for Optional.

D. Prepare to Apply the BMS10-11 Primer

SUBTASK 51-21-72-950-003

(1) Mask the surface adjacent to the area you will apply primer.

(a) Attach the tags that follow to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\1) “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447

\2) “STATIC PORTS COVERED” tag, G02444

\3) A red tag labeled “AOA SENSORS COVERED”

(b) Put a pitot probe cover, COM-1503 on the pitot probe.

(c) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270 on the static ports.

(d) Do the steps that follow to cover the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

\1) Cover the angle-of-attack sensors with PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape.

a) Apply PG-777 over the blade, plate, and blade-to-plate gap.

NOTE: This is to allow easier removal of 3M 425 aluminum tape.

\2) Cover the PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape with 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape,

G00291.

a)

Shingle the aluminum foil tape from the blade-to-plate gap up to the blade tip

until all of the masking tape is covered.

SUBTASK 51-21-72-370-024

(2) Determine which method to use to prepare the surface (Table 709).

SUBTASK 51-21-72-370-023

(3) Use one of the methods that follow to prepare the surface.

(a) Method 1

\1) Solvent clean the surface.

\2) Sand the surface with 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077, if necessary to

clean the surface.

\3) Solvent clean the surface to remove sanding dust.

(b) Method 2

\1) Solvent clean the surface.

\2) Sand the surface with one of the abrasives that follow.

a) Norton Bear-Tex 747 General Purpose Hand Pad, very fine, aluminum oxide

b) Scotch-Brite General Purpose Hand Pad 7447, very fine, aluminum oxide

c) Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish, very fine, aluminum oxide

d) 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077

e) Make sure that you do not sand the substrate.

\4)

Use compressed air or a tack rag, G50123 to remove sanding dust, if necessary.

(c) Method 3

\1) Solvent clean the surface.

a) Use a Scotch-Brite General Purpose Hand Pad 7447 (very fine, aluminum

oxide) or a Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish (very fine, aluminum oxide), if

necessary.

\2) Alkaline clean the surface.

a) Use a Scotch-Brite General Purpose Hand Pad 7447 (very fine, aluminum

oxide) or a Scotch-Brite Clean and Finish (very fine, aluminum oxide) wet with

alkaline cleaner that is diluted with three parts of water, by volume.

b) Make sure that you do not sand the substrate.

c) Use one of the alkaline cleaners that follow.

<1> Ardrox 160-B

<2> Pace B-82 alkaline cleaner, B00017

<3> Pace MF-30 cleaner, B50172

<4> Ridoline 909, B50052

<5> Super Bee 300LF

<6> Turco 4215 NC-LT alkaline cleaner, B50240

\3) Rinse the surface with large amounts of water.

\4) Do a check for a water-break-free surface.

a) If water breaks occur, alkaline clean the surface again and rinse with more

water.

SUBTASK 51-21-72-370-025

(4) Mix the BMS10-11 primer, C00259 using the manufacturer’s instructions.

E. Apply the BMS10-11 Primer

SUBTASK 51-21-72-160-022

(1) Immediately before you apply the BMS10-11 primer, use a tack rag, G50123 to remove loose

dust and lint.

SUBTASK 51-21-72-370-026

(2) Spray or brush apply the BMS10-11 primer, C00259.

(a) Apply the finish in a continuous coat.

(b) Make sure that the coat is free of solids, runs, sags, fish eyes, blisters, and non-adherent

overspray.

SUBTASK 51-21-72-370-027

(3) Cure the primer.

(a) If the primer is applied to surfaces other than tungsten base metal, use Table 710, and

Figure 703 to cure the primer.

entry.title: BOEING章节号51-21-71
entry.content:
737-600/700/800/900 AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

CONDUCTIVE COATING FOR EXTERNAL SURFACES - CLEANING/PAINTING

1. General

A. This procedure has this task:

(1)

Apply Conductive Coating to Specified External Surfaces.

B. When you apply conductive coatings to non-conductive, external airplane surfaces, it is to:

(1) Help discharge static electrical charges to the primary airplane structure, and

(2) Help the positive grounding of the static electrical charges to the airplane structure.

C. You can only use BMS10-21, Type II or IV for the Radome or HF antenna fiberglass panel. If you

use BMS10-21, Type III, the weather radar system or HF communication system will not operate

correctly.

TASK 51-21-71-370-802

2. Apply BMS 10-21 Type II Conductive Coating To Specified External Surfaces

A. References

Reference

Title

51-21-00-100-801

Airplane Surface Preparation for Application of Finish (P/B 701)

B. Tools/Equipment

NOTE: When more than one tool part number is listed under the same “Reference” number, the

tools shown are alternates to each other within the same airplane series. Tool part numbers

that are replaced or non-procurable are preceded by “Opt:”, which stands for Optional.

Reference

Description

COM-1793

Multimeter - Digital/Analog (or equivalent meter meets task

requirements)

Part #: 117 Supplier: 89536

Part #: 260-8XPI Supplier: 55026

Part #: 287 Supplier: 89536

Part #: 289 Supplier: 89536

Part #: 87V Supplier: 89536

Part #: FLUKE 27 II Supplier: 89536

Part #: FLUKE-77-4 Supplier: 89536

Opt Part #: 187 Supplier: 89536

Opt Part #: 189 Supplier: 89536

Opt Part #: 21 Supplier: 89536

Opt Part #: 27 Supplier: 89536

Opt Part #: 87 Supplier: 89536

Opt Part #: FLUKE 27 Supplier: 89536

Opt Part #: MODEL 27 Supplier: 89536

SPL-7885

Probe - Surface Resistivity Measurement

Part #: ST895A-3-1 Supplier: 81205

SPL-10361

Probe - Film Resistance Measure

Part #: F70328-1 Supplier: 81205

Opt Part #: ST895A-1 Supplier: 81205

STD-1080

STD-1133

Gun - Spray, Paint, with Interchangeable Nozzles

737-600/700/800/900

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-71

D633A101-BPA

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryedC. Consumable Materials

Reference

Description

Specification

B00083

Solvent - VM&P Naphthas

TT-N-95 Type II, ASTM

D-3735 Type III

B00102

Abrasive - Aluminum Oxide Coated Cloth

C00841

Coating - Anti-Static Coating

BMS10-21 Type II

G00034

Cotton Wiper - Process Cleaning Absorbent

Wiper (Cheesecloth, Gauze)

AMS3819 Class 1

Grade A or B Form 1

(Supersede BMS15-5

CL A)

G00251

Abrasive - Mat, Non-Woven, Non-Metallic A-A-58054

G50077

Abrasive - Aluminum Oxide Paper, 240 grit or

finer

G50630

Tape - Copper Foil With Conductive Adhesive

(3M 1181 Tape)

D. Procedure

SUBTASK 51-21-71-100-002

WARNING

DO NOT GET THIS MATERIAL IN YOUR MOUTH, EYES, OR ON YOUR SKIN.

CLEAN BARE SKIN FULLY AFTER YOU USE THIS MATERIAL. THIS

MATERIAL CAN CAUSE INJURIES TO PERSONNEL OR DAMAGE TO

EQUIPMENT.

(1) Do this task: (Airplane Surface Preparation for Application of Finish, TASK 51-21-00-100-801).

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-005

(2) Prepare the BMS 10–21 Type II conductive coating, C00841, with the steps as follows:

(a) Refer to the manufacturer’s instructions to mix the conductive coating.

(b) Fully shake each conductive coating component before you mix it.

NOTE: The conductive coating is supplied in two component kits. The kits have a base

component and a catalyst.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-006

(3) Apply the BMS 10–21 Type II conductive coating, C00841, compound with a paint spray gun

with interchangeable nozzles, STD-1133, or paint brush, STD-1080.

(a) Be sure that the temperature for the application of the coating, C00841, must be 40°F

(4°C) to 100°F (38°C). The preferred temperature is 50°F (10°C) to 90°F (32°C).

(b) The dry film thickness after it has been cured must be 0.0008 ±0.0002 in.

(0.0203 ±0.0051 mm).

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-007

(4) Cure the BMS 10–21 Type II conductive coating, C00841, with the steps that follow:

(a) Allow the conductive coating that is in fastener holes cure for at least 20 minutes at 70°F

(21°C) to 90°F (32°C) before you install the fasteners.

(b) Heat-cure the anti-static coating before taking resistivity measurements or overcoating.

\1) The flash-off time necessary before the higher temperature cure is 15 minutes

minimum at 75 ±15°F (24 ±8°C).

737-600/700/800/900

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-71

NoC

Page 702

D633A101-BPA

Jun 15/2022

ECCN 9E991 BOEING PROPRIETARY - See title page for details

EFFECTIVITY

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryed2) Apply heat to cure the conductive coating before you do the resistivity

measurements as shown in (Figure 701).

NOTE: The increased drying time as shown in Figure 701 is not a full cure.

a) Do not cure above 160°F (71°C).

b)

Do not cure at temperatures of 120°F (49°C) or above for longer than 2 hours.

\3) The cool-off time necessary before subsequent processing the cure is 15 minutes

minimum at 75 ±15°F (24 ±8°C).

SUBTASK 51-21-71-700-004

(5) Do the steps that follow to measure the resistivity of the conductive coating

(Fastener-to-Conductive Surface Test Method):

NOTE: The resistivity of the conductive coating after it is cured must be no less than 1

Megohm/square or more than 100 Megohms/square.

NOTE: Let the conductive coat cure for the specified time as shown in (Figure 701) before you

measure the conductivity.

(a)

If the bonding surface and the head of the fastener are covered with a finish, (Figure 702)

do the steps as follows:

\1) Remove a sufficient quantity of the outer coating or paint to let the probes touch the

conductive finish.

NOTE: If it is necessary, you can push the probes through the outer coating.

\2) Put the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793, with the film resistance measure

probe, SPL-10361 in direct contact with the bonding fastener and the conductive

finish.

a) Put the film resistance measure probe, SPL-10361, as shown in Figure 702.

\3) Make a record of the value of the resistivity shown on the multimeter.

a) The minimum permitted resistivity is no less than 1 Megohm/square.

b) The maximum permitted resistivity is 100 Megohms/square.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-700-005

(6) Do the steps that follow to measure the resistivity of the conductive coating on uninstalled

panels (Fastener-to-Fastener Test Method):

NOTE: The resistivity of the conductive coating after it is cured must be no less than 1

Megohm/square or more than 100 Megohms/square.

(a)

Make sure the conductive coating shows in the fastener location.

(b) Clean the area with solvent, B00083.

(c) Install one temporary fastener at each fastener location to be measured. (Figure 702).

NOTE: This procedure can be used for measuring electrical resistivity of panels with

covered (painted) conductive coatings when the ground fastener locations show.

(d)

Connect the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793, probes at the two fastener locations as

shown in (Figure 702).

(e) Measure the resistivity with the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793.

\1) The minimum permitted resistivity is no less than 1 Megohm/square.

\2) The maximum permitted resistivity is 100 Megohms/square.

(f) Remove the temporary fasteners from the surface.

737-600/700/800/900

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-71

NoC

Page 703

D633A101-BPA

Feb 15/2022

ECCN 9E991 BOEING PROPRIETARY - See title page for details

EFFECTIVITY

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryedSUBTASK 51-21-71-700-006

(7)

Use one of the procedures follow to measure the resistivity of the conductive coating (Square

Test Method): (Figure 703)

NOTE: The term ohms/square is used to give the resistance in ohms of current passing from

one side of a square region to the opposite side, regardless of the size of the square.

NOTE: Do not use this procedure to measure the resistivity of conductive finishes when the

surface is covered (painted).

(a)

If the surface resistivity measurement probe, SPL-7885, is used on the conductive

coating surface, do the steps that follow:

\1) Put the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793, with the surface resistivity

measurement probe, SPL-7885, in direct contact with the conductive coating

surface.

\2) Measure the resistivity the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793.

a) The measured value multiplied by 10 gives the value of resistivity in

ohms/square.

NOTE: The term ohms/square is used because it gives the resistance in

ohms of current passing from one side of a square region to the

opposite side, regardless of the size of the square.

NOTE: The minimum resistivity is no less than 1 Megohm/square or a

maximum resistivity of 100 Megohms/square.

(b)

If the 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, is used on the conductive coating surface, do

the steps that follow:

\1) Put two pieces of 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, (of equal length (L)) parallel to

each other on the conductive coating surface.

\2) The two strips of 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, must be put parallel to each

other a distance of one tenth the length of the two strips (0.1L ±5 percent).

\3) Push the two strips of 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, against the conductive

coating.

\4) Measure the resistivity with the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793.

a) The measured value multiplied by 10 gives the value of resistivity in

ohms/square.

NOTE: The term ohms/square is used because it gives the resistance in

ohms of current passing from one side of a square region to the

opposite side, regardless of the size of the square.

NOTE: The minimum resistivity is no less than 1 Megohm/square or a

maximum resistivity of 100 Megohms/square.

\5)

The measured value multiplied by 10 gives the value of resistivity in ohms/square.

\6) Remove the 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, from the surface.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-008

(8) Do the steps that follow if the resistivity of the conductive coating is less than 1

Megohm/Square:

(a) Use 240 grit or finer abrasive cloth, B00102, paper to remove the conductive coating.

NOTE: If the abrasive cloth, B00102, is not available, use a abrasive mat, G00251, or

240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077, as an alternate.

737-600/700/800/900

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-71

NoC

Page 704

D633A101-BPA

Oct 15/2020

ECCN 9E991 BOEING PROPRIETARY - See title page for details

EFFECTIVITY

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryed(b) Remove the remaining particles with a clean cotton wiper, G00034, that is moist with

solvent, B00083.

(c) Dry the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034, before the solvent is dry.

(d) Do the steps to apply a new layer of conductive coating.

(e) Do the steps to cure the conductive coating.

(f) Do the steps to measure the resistivity of the new layer of conductive coating.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-009

(9) Do the steps that follow if the resistivity of the conductive coating is more than 100

Megohms/Square:

(a) Cure at 140°F (60°C) to 160°F (71°C) for 60 to 70 minutes.

(b) Remeasure resistivity.

(c) If the resistivity is more then 100 Megohms/Square, do the steps that follow:

\1) Use 240 grit or finer abrasive cloth, B00102, paper to remove the conductive

coating.

NOTE: If the abrasive cloth, B00102, is not available, use a abrasive mat, G00251,

or 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077, as an alternate.

\2)

Remove the remaining particles with a clean cotton wiper, G00034, that is moist

with solvent, B00083.

\3) Dry the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034, before the solvent is dry.

\4) Do the steps to apply a new layer of conductive coating.

\5) Do the steps to cure the conductive coating.

\6) Do the steps to measure the resistivity of the new layer of conductive coating.

END OF TASK

SUBTASK 51-21-71-100-001

WARNING

DO NOT GET PAINT MATERIALS AND SOLVENTS IN YOUR MOUTH, IN

YOUR EYES, ON YOUR SKIN, OR ON YOUR CLOTHES. DO NOT BREATHE

THE FUMES FROM THESE MATERIALS. MAKE SURE THE AIR FLOWS

FREELY THROUGH THE WORK AREA. USE THE NECESSARY

RESPIRATORY PROTECTION. KEEP THESE MATERIALS AWAY FROM

SPARKS, FLAME, AND TEMPERATURES ABOVE THE FLASH POINT. THESE

MATERIALS ARE POISONOUS AND FLAMMABLE AND CAN CAUSE INJURY

TO PERSONS OR DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.

(1) Do this task: Airplane Surface Preparation for Application of Finish, TASK 51-21-00-100-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-001

CAUTION

DO NOT USE BMS10-21, TYPE III ON THE RADOME OR THE FIBERGLASS

PANEL FOR THE HF ANTENNA. YOU CAN ONLY USE BMS10-21, TYPE II OR

IV ON THESE. IF YOU USE BMS10-21, TYPE III, THE WEATHER RADAR

SYSTEM, AND THE HF COMMUNICATION SYSTEM WILL NOT OPERATE

CORRECTLY.

(2) Prepare the BMS 10-21 Type III conductive coating, C00767, with the steps as follows:

(a) Refer to the manufacturer’s instructions to mix the conductive coating.

(b) Fully shake each conductive coating component before you mix it.

NOTE: The conductive coating is supplied in two component kits. The kits have a base

component and a catalyst.

(c)

Put a label on the container with, the data that follows, immediately after it is mixed:

\1) The date and time it was mixed,

\2) The application time expiration time is as follows:

a) 4 hours if the temperature is less than 81°F (27°C)

b) 2 hours if the temperature is 81°F (27°C) to 100°F (38°C).

(d) Do not use the conductive coating for a minimum of 30 minutes after it is mixed.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-002

(3) Apply the BMS 10-21 Type III conductive coating, C00767, compound with a paint spray gun

with interchangeable nozzles, STD-1133, or paint brush, STD-1080.

(a) Be sure that the temperature for the application of the coating, C00767, must be 40°F

(4°C) to 100°F (38°C). The preferred temperature is 50°F (10°C) to 90°F (32°C).

(b) The dry film thickness after it has been cured must be 0.0006 ±0.0002 in.

(0.0152 ±0.0051 mm).

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-003

(4) Cure the BMS 10-21 Type III conductive coating, C00767, with one of the steps that follow:

(a) Let the conductive coating that is in fastener holes cure for at least 20 minutes at 70°F

(21°C) to 90°F (32°C) before you install the fasteners.

(b) Air dry the surface of the conductive coating for 2 hours at 60°F (16°C).

(c) To cure the conductive coating quickly, apply a minimum temperature of 140°F (60°C)

before you do the resistivity measurements (Figure 701).

NOTE: The increased drying time as shown in Figure 701 is not a full cure.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-700-001

(5) Do the steps that follow to measure the resistivity of the conductive coating

(Fastener-to-Conductive Surface Test Method):

NOTE: The resistivity of the conductive coating after it is cured must be no more than 300,000

ohms/square.

NOTE: Let the conductive coat cure for the specified time as shown in (Figure 701) before you

measure the conductivity.

(a)

If the bonding surface and the head of the fastener are covered with a finish, (Figure 702)

do the steps as follows:

\1) Remove a sufficient quantity of the outer coating or paint to let the probes touch the

conductive finish.

NOTE: If it is necessary, you can push the probes through the outer coating.

\2) Put the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793, with the film resistance measure

probe, SPL-10361, in direct contact with the bonding fastener and the conductive

finish.

a) Put the film resistance measure probe, SPL-10361, as shown in Figure 702.

\3) Make a record of the value of the resistivity shown on the multimeter.

a) The maximum permitted resistivity is 300,000 Ohms/Square.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-700-002

(6) Do the steps that follow to measure the resistivity of the conductive coating on uninstalled

panels (Fastener-to-Fastener Test Method):

NOTE: The resistivity of the conductive coating after it is cured must be no more than 300,000

ohms/square

(a)

Make sure the conductive coating shows in the fastener location.

(b) Clean the area with solvent, B00083.

(c) Install one temporary fastener at each fastener location to be measured. (Figure 702).

NOTE: This procedure can be used for measuring electrical resistivity of panels with

covered (painted) conductive coatings when the ground fastener locations show.

(d)

Connect the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793, probes at the two fastener locations as

shown in (Figure 702).

(e) Measure the resistivity with the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793.

\1) The maximum permitted resistivity is 300,000 Ohms/Square.

(f) Remove the temporary fasteners from the surface.

(7)

Use one of the procedures that follow to measure the resistivity of the conductive coating

(Square Test Method): (Figure 703).

NOTE: The term ohms/square is used to give the resistance in ohms of current passing from

one side of a square region to the opposite side, regardless of the size of the square.

NOTE: Do not use this procedure to measure the resistivity of conductive finishes when the

surface is covered (painted).

(a)

If the surface resistivity measurement probe, SPL-7885, is used on the conductive

coating surface, do the steps that follow:

\1) Put the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793, with the surface resistivity

measurement probe, SPL-7885, in direct contact with the conductive coating

surface.

\2) Measure the resistivity the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793.

a) The measured value multiplied by 10 gives the value of resistivity in

ohms/square.

NOTE: The term ohms/square is used because it gives the resistance in

ohms of current passing from one side of a square region to the

opposite side, regardless of the size of the square.

NOTE: The maximum permitted resistivity is 300,000 Ohms/square.

(b) If the 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, is used on the conductive coating surface, do

the steps that follow:

\1) Put two pieces of 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, (of equal length (L)) parallel to

each other on the conductive coating surface.

\2) The two strips of 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, must be put parallel to each

other a distance of one tenth the length of the two strips (0.1L ±5 percent).

\3) Push the two strips of 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, against the conductive

coating.

\4) Measure the resistivity with the digital/analog multimeter, COM-1793.

a) The measured value multiplied by 10 gives the value of resistivity in

ohms/square.

NOTE: The term ohms/square is used because it gives the resistance in

ohms of current passing from one side of a square region to the

opposite side, regardless of the size of the square.

NOTE: The maximum permitted resistivity is 300,000 Ohms/square.

\5) The measured value multiplied by 10 gives the value of resistivity in ohms/square.

\6)

Remove the 3M 1181 copper foil tape, G50630, from the surface.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-004

(8) Do the steps that follow if the resistivity of the conductive coating is more than 300,000

ohms/square:

(a) Use 240 grit or finer abrasive cloth, B00102, paper to remove the conductive coating.

NOTE: If the abrasive cloth, B00102, is not available, use a abrasive mat, G00251, or

240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077, as an alternate.

(b)

Remove the remaining particles with a clean cotton wiper, G00034, that is moist with

solvent, B00083.

(1) Do this task: (Airplane Surface Preparation for Application of Finish, TASK 51-21-00-100-801).

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-010

(2) Prepare the BMS 10–21 Type IV conductive coating, C50219, with the steps as follows:

(a) Refer to the manufacturer’s instructions to mix the conductive coating.

(b) Fully shake each conductive coating component before you mix it.

NOTE: The conductive coating is supplied in two component kits. The kits have a base

component and a catalyst.

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-011

(3) Apply the BMS 10–21 Type IV conductive coating, C50219, compound with a paint spray gun

with interchangeable nozzles, STD-1133, or paint brush, STD-1080.

(a) Be sure that the temperature for the application of the coating, C50219, must be 40°F

(4°C) to 100°F (38°C). The preferred temperature is 50°F (10°C) to 90°F (32°C).

(0.0203 ±0.0051 mm).

SUBTASK 51-21-71-370-012

(a) Allow the conductive coating that is in fastener holes cure for at least 20 minutes at 70°F

(21°C) to 90°F (32°C) before you install the fasteners.

\3) The cool-off time necessary before subsequent processing the cure is 15 minutes

minimum at 75 ±15°F (24 ±8°C).

Megohms/Square:

(a) Cure at 140°F (60°C) to 160°F (71°C) for 60 to 70 minutes.

(b) Remeasure resistivity.

(c) If the resistivity is more then 100 Megohms/Square, do the steps that follow:

\1) Use 240 grit or finer abrasive cloth, B00102, paper to remove the conductive

coating.

NOTE: If the abrasive cloth, B00102, is not available, use a abrasive mat, G00251,

or 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077, as an alternate.

\2)

Remove the remaining particles with a clean cotton wiper, G00034, that is moist

with solvent, B00083.

\3) Dry the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034, before the solvent is dry.

\4) Do the steps to apply a new layer of conductive coating.

\5) Do the steps to cure the conductive coating.

\6) Do the steps to measure the resistivity of the new layer of conductive coating

entry.title: BOEING章节号51-21-21
entry.content:
737-600/700/800/900 AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

PREPAINT CLEANING AND TREATMENT - CLEANING/PAINTING

1. General

A. This procedure has these tasks:

(1)

Clean the Surface to be Painted

(2) Prepare the Surface to be Painted

(3) Cleaning and Preparation of Internal and External Plastic Surfaces.

B. The surface preparations in this document have different preparation procedures, and cleaning

materials for the different types of surface materials.

C. All airplane surfaces must be cleaned and correctly prepared before you apply the paint.

D. The initial abrade (sanding) of laminates that are not covered with Tedlar is to provide a slight

roughening of the surface.

NOTE: Do not abrade (sand) the laminate to make the surface smooth; but, apply a surface primer

before you paint and then do the sanding.

(1)

The rough surface is to provide for a better bonding of the paint.

TASK 51-21-21-100-801

2. Clean the Surface to be Painted

A. References

Reference

Title

51-21-11-150-801

Paint Stripping (P/B 701)

51-31-00-160-801

Prepare For Sealing (P/B 201)

NOTE: When more than one tool part number is listed under the same “Reference” number, the

tools shown are alternates to each other within the same airplane series. Tool part numbers

that are replaced or non-procurable are preceded by “Opt:”, which stands for Optional.

COVERED” - 3 inches (76.2 mm) Wide, 6

inches (152.4 mm) Long

D. Clean the Surface

SUBTASK 51-21-21-110-001

(1) Do the steps that follow to clean the surface:

NOTE: Use solvent, B00083, or solvent, B00074, for this step.

WARNING

DO NOT GET ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA OR DRY CLEANING SOLVENT IN

YOUR MOUTH, YOUR EYES, OR ON YOUR SKIN. DO NOT BREATHE

THE FUMES FROM THE ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA OR DRY CLEANING

SOLVENT. PUT ON PROTECTIVE SPLASH GOGGLES AND GLOVES

WHEN YOU USE ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA OR DRY CLEANING SOLVENT.

KEEP ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA OR DRY CLEANING SOLVENT AWAY FROM

SPARKS, FLAME, AND TEMPERATURES ABOVE THE FLASH POINT.

ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA OR DRY CLEANING SOLVENT IS A POISONOUS

AND FLAMMABLE SOLVENT WHICH CAN CAUSE INJURY TO PERSONS

AND DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.

(a) Remove the loose dirt, grease, and oil with cotton wiper, G00034, that is moist with

solvent, B00074, or solvent, B00083.

NOTE: Be careful not to put solvent on an area that is larger than is necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034, soft paint brush, STD-1080, or a sponge,

G00116, that is moist with solvent, B00074, or solvent, B00083.

NOTE: You can use a spray gun to help clean the surface.

(c) Flush the surface with clean solvent, B00074, or solvent, B00083.

\1)

Rub the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034, to remove all of the dirt.

(d) Remove all unwanted solvent.

(e) Let the surface dry.

(f) Attach the tags that follow to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\1) “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447

\2) “STATIC PORTS COVERED” tag, G02444

737-600/700/800/900

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-21

NoC

Page 702

D633A101-BPA

Jun 15/2022

ECCN 9E991 BOEING PROPRIETARY - See title page for details

EFFECTIVITY

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryed3) A red tag labeled “AOA SENSORS COVERED”

(g)

Put a pitot probe cover, COM-1503, on the pitot probes.

(h) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270, to the static ports.

(i) Do the steps that follow to cover the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

\1) Cover the angle-of-attack sensors with PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape.

a) Apply PG-777 over the blade, plate, and blade-to-plate gap.

NOTE: This is to allow easier removal of 3M 425 aluminum tape.

\2) Cover the PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape with 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape,

G00291.

a)

Shingle the aluminum foil tape from the blade-to-plate gap up to the blade tip

until all of the masking tape is covered.

SUBTASK 51-21-21-110-002

(2) Do the steps that follow to clean the area again:

WARNING

DO NOT GET ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA IN YOUR MOUTH, YOUR EYES, OR

ON YOUR SKIN. DO NOT BREATHE THE FUMES FROM THE ALIPHATIC

NAPHTHA. PUT ON PROTECTIVE SPLASH GOGGLES AND GLOVES

WHEN YOU USE ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA. KEEP ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA

AWAY FROM SPARKS, FLAME, AND TEMPERATURES ABOVE THE

FLASHPOINT. ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA IS A POISONOUS AND FLAMMABLE

SOLVENT WHICH CAN CAUSE INJURY TO PERSONS AND DAMAGE TO

EQUIPMENT.

CAUTION

YOU MUST FULLY CLEAN THE SURFACE BEFORE YOU APPLY PAINTS

OR ADHESIVES. USE ALIPHATIC NAPHTHA IN THE LAST STEP OF THE

PROCEDURE TO CLEAN THE SURFACE. DO NOT USE P-D-680 TYPE I

FOR THE LAST STEP OF THE PROCEDURE TO CLEAN THE SURFACE.

DAMAGE TO THE SURFACE CAN OCCUR IF P-D-680 TYPE I IS USED IN

THE LAST STEP.

(a) Use a spray bottle to apply the Aliphatic Naphtha solvent, B00083 to the surface.

(b) Clean the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034, until all large pieces of dirt are

removed.

NOTE: Use a soft bristle brush to clean if it is necessary.

(c) Clean the surface again until no signs of the dirt are found on a clean cotton wiper,

G00034.

(d)

Dry the area with a clean dry cotton wiper, G00034.

NOTE: Do not let drops of solvent dry on the surface.

E. Removal of the Temporary Finishes

SUBTASK 51-21-21-150-002

(1) Prepare to remove the temporary finishes.

737-600/700/800/900

DO NOT USE PAINT STRIPPER ON COMPOSITE MATERIALS. PAINT

STRIPPERS CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE STRUCTURE OF THE PART.

(a) Apply masking Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270, to the areas that will not

have the stripper applied.

NOTE: Put masking tape also on the areas that will be damaged by the paint stripper.

(b) Put applicable covers plastic coated paper, G00365, on areas which are easily damaged

by the strippers.

NOTE: You can use equivalent plastic sheeting which is resistant to paint strippers.

\1) Use some of the materials that follow to protect the surface:

a)

Paper masking tape.

b) Plastic coated paper.

c) Plastic sheeting.

d) Wrapping paper, chemically neutral.

(c) Attach the tags that follow to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\1) “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447

\2) “STATIC PORTS COVERED” tag, G02444

\3) A red tag labeled “AOA SENSORS COVERED”

(d) Install the pitot probe cover, COM-1503, on the pitot probes.

(e) Use Scotch Brand No.471 tape, G02219, and barricade tape, G02443, to cover the static

ports.

(f) Do the steps that follow to cover the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

\1) Cover the angle-of-attack sensors with PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape.

a) Apply PG-777 over the blade, plate, and blade-to-plate gap.

NOTE: This is to allow easier removal of 3M 425 aluminum tape.

\2) Cover the PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape with 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape,

G00291.

a)

Shingle the aluminum foil tape from the blade-to-plate gap up to the blade tip

until all of the masking tape is covered.

SUBTASK 51-21-21-150-001

(2) Remove the applicable temporary finishes if it is necessary, do this task: Paint Stripping,

TASK 51-21-11-150-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-21-390-001

(3) Repair all damaged sealant, do this task: Prepare For Sealing, TASK 51-31-00-160-801.

END OF TASK

TASK 51-21-21-370-801

3.

Prepare the Surface to be Painted

(a) Make sure that covers are put on the components that follow:

\2) Aluminum (metal sprayed) - chemical treated

(h) Do the Procedure 2 as follows:

NOTE: Use the cleaners compound, B00314 or cleaner, B00402. Dilute the cleaners to 1

part cleaner to 10 parts of water by volume.

NOTE: The following cleaners are optional for cleaner, B00402: Cee Bee 280 cleaner,

B00005, Oakite 204 cleaner, B00008 and Calla 301A cleaner, B00015.

\1)

Clean the surface with cotton wiper, G00034, soft paint brush, STD-1080, or a

sponge, G00116 that is moist with cleaners compound, B00314 or cleaner, B00402.

NOTE: Do not clean too large an area at one time.

\2) Let the cleaner soak for approximately 5 minutes.

NOTE: Do not let the cleaner dry on the surface because it can cause the surface

to be stained.

\3)

Flush the area thoroughly with clean warm water (120°F maximum).

a) Apply the water by pressure spray if it is available.

b) Flush the area to remove cleaner residue.

\4) Make sure all of the cleaner is removed.

\5) Reclean the area if it is necessary to make sure all of the dirt has been removed.

a) Pressure clean with a non-atomizing spray gun.

NOTE: You must use a minimum impingement time of 5 seconds, with a

maximum stand time of 15 minutes.

NOTE: Do not let the cleaner dry on the surface.

\6) Flush the surface thoroughly with clean water (hot water preferred) to remove all of

the cleaner residues.

NOTE: Pressure spray or an air-water rinse is recommended.

a) Make sure that all of the cleaner has been removed with a check of the run-off

with pH paper.

NOTE: The pH must be the same as tap water.

WARNING

DO NOT GET SOLVENTS IN YOUR MOUTH, EYES, OR SKIN AND

DO NOT BREATHE THE FUMES FROM SOLVENTS. SOLVENTS ARE

HAZARDOUS MATERIALS. REFER TO PRODUCT MATERIAL

SAFETY DATA SHEETS (MSDS) AND LOCAL REQUIREMENTS FOR

CORRECT HANDLING PROCEDURES. IF YOU DO NOT OBEY,

INJURY TO PERSONNEL CAN OCCUR.

\7) Manual solvent clean the surface with Series 85 solvent, B01005

(TASK 20-30-85-910-801).

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-21

NoC

EFFECTIVITY

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryed8) Less than 48 hours after you have cleaned the surface with alkaline cleaners, clean

the surface with one of the steps that follow:

NOTE: Use a 1 to 1 solution of De Soto Oxsolv and water (or an applicable

equivalent).

a)

Manually clean the surface.

b) Pressure clean the surface with a non-atomizing spray gun.

NOTE: You must use a minimum impingement time of 5 seconds, with a

maximum stand time of 2 minutes.

NOTE: Do not let the cleaner dry on the surface.

\9) Use cotton wiper, G00034 to remove wet solvent.

\10)

Solvent clean with PR-148 (clear) Adhesion Promoter solvent, B00635 with one of

the steps that follow:

a) Manually clean the surface.

b) Pressure clean the surface with a non-atomizing spray gun.

NOTE: You must use a minimum impingement time of 5 seconds, with a

maximum stand time of 2 minutes.

\11) Blow dry the surface with filtered compressed air.

(i) Do the Procedure 3 as follows:

\1) Clean the surface.

NOTE: Abrasive pads (Scotch-brite) are recommended as an aid to remove

stubborn dirt.

a)

Flush the surface with water until you get a water break-free surface.

NOTE: A water break-free surface will let a continuous layer of water stay on

the surface for 30 seconds.

b)

Make sure you flush all unwanted material from the joints and fasteners.

\2) Thoroughly flush the surface with clean water to remove all remaining sanded and

cleaner material.

NOTE: If you do not get a water-break-free surface, clean the surface again.

\3) If the substrate shows, use the applicable specifications to apply a new surface

layer.

\4) Thoroughly dry the surface before it is painted.

SUBTASK 51-21-21-100-004

(5) Prepare all adhesive primers with one of the three procedures that follow:.

(a) Do the Procedure 1.

\1) Manually solvent clean the surface.

\2) Abrasive clean with 320 grit or finer aluminum oxide abrasive cloth, B00102.

NOTE: Make sure you do not cause the substrate to show.

Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034, soft paint brush, STD-1080, or a

\5) Reclean the area if it is necessary to make sure all of the dirt has been removed.

NOTE: You must use a minimum impingement time of 5 seconds, with a

NOTE: Do not let the cleaner dry on the surface.

\6) Flush the surface thoroughly with clean water (hot water preferred) to remove all of

the cleaner residues.

NOTE: Pressure spray or an air-water rinse is recommended.

with pH paper.

NOTE: The pH must be the same as tap water.

DO NOT GET SOLVENTS IN YOUR MOUTH, EYES, OR SKIN AND

DO NOT BREATHE THE FUMES FROM SOLVENTS. SOLVENTS ARE

HAZARDOUS MATERIALS. REFER TO PRODUCT MATERIAL

SAFETY DATA SHEETS (MSDS) AND LOCAL REQUIREMENTS FOR

CORRECT HANDLING PROCEDURES. IF YOU DO NOT OBEY,

INJURY TO PERSONNEL CAN OCCUR.

(TASK 20-30-85-910-801).

stubborn dirt.

\2)

Clean the surface with abrasive cloth, B00102 that are moist with cleaner

compound, B00314 or cleaner, B00402 to make the surface rough.

NOTE: The following cleaners are optional for cleaner, B00402: Cee Bee 280

cleaner, B00005, Oakite 204 cleaner, B00008 and Calla 301A cleaner,

B00015.

NOTE: Dilute the cleaners with 1 part cleaner with 10 parts of water by volume.

a) Flush the surface with water until you get a water break-free surface.

NOTE: A water break-free surface will let a continuous layer of water stay on

the surface for 30 seconds.

b)

Make sure you flush all unwanted material from the joints and fasteners.

\3) Thoroughly flush the surface with clean water to remove all remaining sanding and

cleaner material.

NOTE: If you do not get a water-break-free surface, clean the surface again.

\4) If the substrate shows, use the applicable specification to apply a new surface layer.

\5)

Thoroughly dry the surface before it is painted.

(a) Do the Procedure 1 as follows:

entry.title: BOEING章节号51-21-11
entry.content:
737-600/700/800/900 AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

PAINT STRIPPING - CLEANING/PAINTING

1. General

A. This procedure has these tasks:

(1)

Prepare for Paint Stripping

(2) Paint Stripping

(3) Ferrous Alloys - Paint Stripping

(4) Titanium - Paint Stripping

(5) Titanium Alloys - Paint Stripping

(6) Titanium-Cadmium - Paint Stripping

(7) Nickel - Paint Stripping

(8) Nickel Alloys - Paint Stripping

(9) Magnesium Alloys - Paint Stripping

(10) Magnesium - Paint Stripping

(11) Aluminum Alloys - Paint Stripping

(12) Cadmium - Paint Stripping

(13) Zinc-Nickel - Paint Stripping

(14) Chromium - Paint Stripping

(15) Copper-Plating - Paint Stripping

(16) Composite Parts - Paint Stripping

B. Paint strippers or solvents are used to remove small quantities of paint on metal surfaces. Do not

use paint stripper on plastic laminations, fiberglass, aerodynamic smoother, edges of metal bonds,

or rubber parts. Use only approved solvents for these materials.

CAUTION

DO NOT USE PAINT STRIPPER ON COMPOSITE MATERIALS. PAINT

STRIPPERS CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE STRUCTURE OF THE PART.

(1) Use dry abrasive methods to remove the paint from the composite surfaces.

(a) For composites, the recommended abrasive is No. 240 Scotch-Brite. Use of alternative

blasting procedures for finish removal is structurally satisfactory. The procedure must

agree with the requirements given in SAE MA4872, “Paint Stripping of Commercial

Aircraft - Evaluation of Materials and Processes”. Refer to SOPM 20-30-02, or BAC5725,

“Stripping Organic Materials” for more information on paint stripping with blast media.

TASK 51-21-11-370-801

2. Prepare for Paint Stripping

A. General

(1)

The purpose of alkaline cleaning is to prepare the painted surfaces of the aircraft for paint

stripping. Paint strippers can be more effective if the aircraft surface is cleaned prior to paint

stripping.

DAMAGE TO COMPONENTS WITH THESE MATERIALS.

cannot be used on high-strength steel or magnesium.

E. Prepare for Paint Stripping

SUBTASK 51-21-11-580-001

(1) Ground the airplane (AIRPLANE GROUNDING - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES,

PAGEBLOCK 20-40-11/201).

SUBTASK 51-21-11-020-001

(2) Remove windshield wipers, as required.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-002

(3) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270 to areas that you will not strip, or to areas

that can be damaged easily by the paint strippers.

(a) Pitot static probes and ports.

\1) Attach a “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447 and “STATIC PORTS

COVERED” tag, G02444 to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

(b) Total air temperature (TAT) probe.

(c) Cooling air exhaust duct.

(d) Windshield wiper mounts.

(e) Cargo door and entry door hinges and thresholds.

(f) Mask all gaps containing mechanical (silicone rubber) seals.

NOTE: This is to prevent seal degradation.

(g) Mask unsealed Section 48 seams and other open joints that cannot be thoroughly rinsed.

(h)

Put the applicable tape or covers on lubricated parts, rubber parts, laminated plastics,

fiberglass, aerodynamic smoother, and metal-bonded edges.

(i) Apply tape a minimum of 1 in. (25 mm) wide on the skin to all access doors, fairings, wing

leading edges and trailing edges.

(j) Apply tape on the drain holes and vents.

(k) Apply tape on the pressurized drain valves.

(l) Acrylic parts.

(m) Glass parts.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-052

(4) If you will use restricted strippers (Table 701), do the steps that follow.

(a) Mask beyond the areas of sealant that follow.

NOTE: This is to prevent penetration to the joint.

\1) Lap joint sealant.

\3)

Aerodynamic window sealants.

(b) Double-mask windows, high-strength steel cargo doors and hinges.

\1) Apply a second layer of aluminum tape that is offset from the initial application of

tape by 50%.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-840-001

(5) Install the (AOA) sensor angle of attack vane cover, COM-2499 (recommended) or AOA vane

protective cover, SPL-14189 (alternate).

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-053

(6) Mask the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

(a) Attach a red tag with wire to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\1) Write “AOA SENSORS COVERED” on the tag.

(b) Cover the angle-of-attack sensors with PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape.

\1) Apply PG-777 over the blade, plate, and blade-to-plate gap (Figure 703).

NOTE: This is to allow easier removal of 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape, G00291.

\2) Cover the PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape with 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape,

G00291.

a)

Shingle the aluminum foil tape from the blade-to-plate gap up to the blade tip

until all of the masking tape is covered.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-054

(7) Put applicable plastic coated paper, G00365 covers on areas which are easily damaged by

strippers.

NOTE: You can use equivalent plastic sheeting that is resistant to paint strippers.

(a) Use the applicable material below to protect the surface.

\1)

Paper masking tape.

\2) Plastic-coated paper.

\3) Plastic sheeting.

\4) Wrapping paper, chemically neutral.

(b) Cover the areas that follow with the applicable cover.

\1) Wings.

a) Put the flaps in the full up position (Retract the Trailing Edge Flaps,

TASK 27-51-00-860-804, Leading Edge Flaps and Slats Retraction,

TASK 27-81-00-860-804).

\2) Tires.

\3) Engine and APU inlets and exhaust.

\4) Ram air inlets.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-003

(8) Cover the passenger and flight deck windows with the steps that follow (Figure 702).

(a) Use Protex 10VS tape, G50394, Protex 20V tape, G00139, pre-cut plastic adhesive

window mask paper (8216-2L), or Polyethylene-coated Kraft paper.

\1) Make sure that the polyethylene-coated Kraft paper is at least 0.001 in. (0.025 mm)

thick.

(b)

Use tape, G02321 to attach the paper to the airplane surface.

\1) Use a hand series squeegee applicator, STD-10211 to make sure the tape adheres

to the surface.

(c) Apply Scotch 427 Aluminum Foil Tape, G50737 over the masking tape.

\1) Make sure that the aluminum foil tape extends beyond the window onto the frame or

forging.

\2) Use a hand series squeegee applicator, STD-10211 to make sure the tape adheres

to the surface.

(d) Apply an aluminum cover to the windows.

\1) Make sure that the aluminum cover is 0.01 in. (0.25 mm) to 0.04 in. (1.02 mm) thick.

\2) Use 2 in. (51 mm) thick masking tape (PG-777) to attach the aluminum cover.

a) Apply the masking tape in strips that are shingled (bottom to top in overlapping

layers, see Figure 702).

NOTE: This will help to stop fluids from seeping under the tape.

\3) Put Scotch 427 Aluminum Foil Tape, G50737 on top of the masking tape.

(e)

If you will strip paint in an area within 2 in. (51 mm) of a window pane, or if you will use a

restricted use paint stripper, do the steps that follow.

\1) Double-mask the windows.

\2) Do the paint stripping procedure twice.

\3) See Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-150-801 for a list of restricted use paint

strippers.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-004

CAUTION

DO NOT USE RESTRICTED-USE PAINT STRIPPERS ON HIGH-STRENGTH

STEEL, OR MAGNESIUM COMPONENTS. THESE STRIPPERS WILL CAUSE

DAMAGE TO COMPONENTS WITH THESE MATERIALS.

(9) Drape-mask landing gear and wheel wells.

NOTE: Make sure to lay down the polyethylene before you roll the airplane into the hangar.

This will make sure the entire wheels and tires are masked.

(a)

Use polyethylene film, G00252.

(b) Use PG-777 masking tape to attach the polyethylene film.

\1) Make sure that the Polyken tape does not come into contact with the aircraft.

(c) Use Scotch 427 Aluminum Foil Tape, G50737 on top of the masking tape and Polyken

tape.

\1) Make sure that the aluminum tape is 2 in. (51 mm) thick.

(d) Use a hand series squeegee applicator, STD-10211 to make sure that the tape adheres

to the surface.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-007

(10) Mask the composite areas listed below using the steps that follow if they will not be stripped of

paint.

(a) Composite surfaces (Figure 701).
