(12) Do the steps that follow to clean the area.

(a) Remove the loose dirt, grease, and oil with MIL-PRF-680 degreasing solvent, B00074 or

aliphatic naphtha solvent, B00083.

NOTE: Be careful to not put solvent on a larger area than it is necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034, paint brush, STD-1080, or a sponge,

G00116 that is moist with MIL-PRF-680 degreasing solvent, B00074 or aliphatic naphtha

solvent, B00083.

\1) Rub the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034.

(c) Remove all unwanted solvent.

(d) Let the surface dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-097

(13) Do the steps that follow to clean the surface again.

(a) Use a spray bottle to apply the aliphatic naphtha solvent, B00083 on the surface.

(b) Clean the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034 until you remove all large pieces of

soil.

\1) Use a soft bristle brush, G00215 to clean the surface, if it is necessary.

(c) Clean the surface again with a new cotton wiper, G00034 until you can see no signs of

soil on the cheesecloth.

NOTE: It will be necessary to change the cheesecloth frequently when you clean the

surface.

(d)

Dry the area with a clean cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that you do not let drops of solvent dry on the surface.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-580-002

(14) Dry the aircraft.

(a) If actuator components or bearings were cleaned, lubricate those components as

necessary.

\1) Make sure to lubricate the actuator components or bearings outside the paint

hangar.

NOTE: This is to avoid paint contamination.

END OF TASK

3.

Paint Stripping

A. General

(1)

This task has the following steps:

(a) Brush-on or paint-on paint stripping

(b) A removal of the epoxy adhesives and adhesive primers

(c) A removal of the rain erosion coating from fiberglass

(d) Selection of paint strippers.

CAUTION

DO NOT LET PAINT STRIPPERS TOUCH FIBREGLASS, ACRYLIC WINDOWS,

SEALANT FILLETS, TEFLON LINED SELF-LUBRICATED BEARINGS,

ELECTRICAL TERMINAL PLUGS, NYLON COATED WIRES AND NYLON

BUSHINGS. THE CHEMICAL COMPOUNDS IN THE PAINT STRIPPERS WILL

CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE COMPONENTS.

(2) Before you clean, you must protect the surfaces and parts which are easily damaged by paint

strippers.

(a) Make sure that the paint strippers do not fall on the joints.

(b) Do not use paint strippers in the fuel tanks.

(3) Before you remove the paint with the stripping procedure, make sure that the surface is clean

and dry.

(a) Make sure that the ambient temperature is between 50°F (10°C) and 100°F (38°C).

\1) Do not use the stripping procedure in hot or wet weather.

(b) Make sure that the paint stripping equipment are fully clean of chemical residue.

NOTE: Refer to equipment manufacturer’s instructions to clean paint stripping

equipment.

CAUTION

DO NOT USE PAINT STRIPPER ON COMPOSITE MATERIALS. PAINT

STRIPPERS CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE STRUCTURE OF THE PART.

(4) Brush-on or spray-on stripping methods with paint strippers or solvents can be used on metal

surfaces.

(a) You can use a pressure sprayer gun, STD-447, or a brush to apply the paint strippers.

\1) The brush-on procedure is frequently used for line maintenance.

CAUTION

DO NOT USE THE SAME PUMPS AND HOSES WHEN MIXING DRUMS

OF DIFFERENT PAINT STRIPPERS THROUGH RECIRCULATION.

MIXING AND CROSS-CONTAMINATION CAN BE HIGHLY CORROSIVE

TO METAL SURFACES. THIS CAN CAUSE SKIN PITTING DAMAGE.

(b) Make sure that the components in the paint stripper are fully mixed.

\1) Do not use the same pumps and hoses when drums of different paint strippers are

mixed through recirculation.

a) Use dedicated pump and hose for different paint stripper type when drums of

paint striper are mixed through recirculation.

CAUTION

DO NOT APPLY ACID-ACTIVATED STRIPPER ONTO ANY AIRPLANE

SURFACE THAT HAS NOT HAD THE PEROXIDE-ACTIVATED STRIPPER

COMPLETELY AND THOROUGHLY RINSED OFF WITH WATER AND

VICE-VERSA. IF YOU MIX AND CROSS-CONTAMINATE, IT CAN BE

HIGHLY CORROSIVE TO METAL SURFACES. THIS CAN CAUSE SKIN

PITTING DAMAGE.

(c) Do not mix strippers of different manufacturers.

\1) Make sure that airplane is completely and thoroughly rinsed down with water to

remove all residue of the initial paint stripper when using different paint stripper.

\2) Do not apply acid-activated stripper onto any airplane surface that has not had the

peroxide-activated stripper completely and thoroughly rinsed off with water and

vise-versa.

NOTE: If necessary, a mild alkaline cleaner solution can be used to neutralize the

hydrogen-peroxide paint based stripper. You can use Super Bee 300LF

cleaner, B50394 [CP2615] or other equivalent cleaners approved for aircraft

exteriors to remove paint and stripper residue.

(d) Strippers that you apply with a brush or with a spray gun contain agents that make a

solution thick.

\1) Apply these strippers on the vertical and horizontal surfaces.

(e) Strippers that you apply with a cloth are used to remove temporary finishes, waxes, and

oversprays.

(f) Boeing specifications BAC5725 and BAC5771 provide procedures for paint stripping.

(g) Restricted strippers are not compatible with high-strength steel and magnesium. When

you use restricted strippers, make sure that all high-strength steel and magnesium parts

are masked.

(h) Acid strippers will discolor clad aluminum.

(i) You can usually use a solvent to remove small quantities of paint.

(j) Do not use paint strippers on the surfaces that follow:

NOTE: Only use approved solvents on these materials.

\1) Plastic laminates

\2)

Fiberglass

\3) Aerodynamic smoother

\4) Edges of metal bonds

\5) Rubber parts

\6) Lubricated parts

\7) Composite surfaces or parts.

(5) Abrasive stripping methods can be used on the surfaces that follow:

(a) Ferrous Alloys

(b) Titanium

(c) Titanium Alloys

(d) Titanium-Cadmium

(2) Do the paint stripping.

NOTE: Strip only an area that can be worked at one time.

Make sure that you double-strip windows.

\3) Make sure that the stripper does not touch or fall on aluminum surfaces.

CAUTION

DO NOT USE ABRASIVE PADS (SCOTCH-BRITE), OR ABRASIVE PAPER

ON THE ALUMINUM SURFACE UNLESS THE SCRIBE LINE

INSPECTIONS WERE MADE. ABRASIVE PADS CAN SMOOTH THE

ALUMINUM SURFACE AND HIDE THE SCRIBE LINE MARKS. IF YOU

USE ABRASIVE PADS TO REMOVE THE PAINT OR PRIMER BEFORE

YOU DO THE SCRIBE LINE INSPECTIONS, YOU CAN BE REQUIRED TO

DO REPEAT INSPECTIONS BASED ON THE SCRIBE LINE INSPECTION

SERVICE BULLETIN.

CAUTION

ONLY USE APPROVED SCRAPERS ON THE AIRPLANE SKIN.

SCRAPERS THAT ARE NOT APPROVED CAN MAKE SCRATCHES ON

THE SKIN, AND CAUSE FATIGUE CRACKS.

(d) Remove the stripper and loosened adhesive, or the primer with cotton wiper, G00034, or

a sealant removal tool, COM-2481, with sealant removal tool handle, COM-4746.

NOTE: If you use abrasive pads before you do scribe line inspections, you can be

required to do repeat inspections based on the scribe line inspection Service

Bulletin 737-53A1289.

(e) If it is necessary, apply the stripper again to remove all unwanted adhesive or the primer.

(f) Rinse the surface with sponge, G00116, that is soaked with clean water.

WARNING

DO NOT GET SOLVENTS IN YOUR MOUTH, YOUR EYES, OR ON

YOUR SKIN. DO NOT BREATHE THE FUMES FROM SOLVENTS.

SOLVENTS ARE DANGEROUS MATERIALS. SOLVENTS CAN BE

FLAMMABLE. OBEY THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS (MSDS)

FOR SOLVENTS. OBEY LOCAL REGULATIONS FOR THE CORRECT

PROCEDURES TO USE OR DISCARD SOLVENTS. SOLVENTS CAN

CAUSE INJURIES TO PERSONNEL AND DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT.

\1) As an alternative to water, you can use Series 84 solvent, B01004, to clean the

surface.

(g) Dry the surface fully with a clean dry cotton wiper, G00034.

F. Remove the Rain Erosion Coating from Fiberglass

SUBTASK 51-21-11-150-024

(1) Prepare the surface for the paint stripping, do this task: Prepare for Paint Stripping,

TASK 51-21-11-370-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-150-005

(2) Do the stripping to remove the rain erosion coating.

*[1] Mixing or cross-contamination of acid-activated strippers with hydrogen peroxide-activated strippers can be highly

corrosive to metal surfaces. Before applying any paint strippers, special attention must be taken to:

\1) Thoroughly clean paint stripping equipment (spray guns, pots, pumps, pressure hoses, etc.) of any chemical

residue from prior usage per equipment manufacturer’s instructions. It is recommended to recirculate water through

the pump, hose, and spray gun at least 5X the volume of the hose and pump. After recirculation, check the pH of the

rinsate to verify it is the same pH as the water source. Scrub clean ID of pump/hose/gun from any material buildup

and thoroughly clean OD of spray gun. Clean squeegees and all tools contacting airplane surface.

\2) Ensure stripper is homogeneous by agitating material for a minimum of 30 minutes** (e.g with a drum roller or

recirculating material with cleaned pump/hose/gun). **this depends on if using a 55 gal drum or a large tote.

\3) Prior to applying stripper to the airplane, it is recommended to apply stripper from each lot (agitiated per step 2) to

abraded 2024-T3 clad panels. Allow the stripper to dwell and wipe off stripper at 4 and 8 hours. Use various sources

of lighting and magnification to inspect the panel for pitting. This is intended to identify any issues with stripper

material or equipment contamination prior to stripping the aircraft.

\4) If one type of paint stripper (e.g. peroxide-activated) is used on an aircraft and it is determined that a different type

of stripper is required (e.g. acid-activated), then the aircraft must be completely and thoroughly rinsed down with

water to remove all residue of the initial paint stripper. Do not apply acid-activated stripper onto any aircraft surface

that has not had the peroxide-activated stripper completely and thoroughly rinsed off with water.

*[2] Do not allow these peroxide-based strippers to come in contact directly with unpainted steel alloys. A thin layer of

these paint strippers can cause corrosion. In using these strippers, expose paint chips and spent strippers to a fine

spray of soap during clean-up after stripping, or rinse paint chips with water to remove paint stripper prior to

packaging in vented containers before disposal. Dispense the stripper through plastic or stainless steel equipment.

Collecting wastes in rusty drums, mixing conversion coating rise water with stripper residues, or throwing rags,

gloves, or other fabrics into the waste drum may cause combustion. Used material contaminated with paint flakes and

organic materials may undergo spontaneous pressurization. The paint stripper produces water and oxygen during the

paint removal process. This process will continue after the stripper is removed form the aircraft. To prevent pressure

from building up in waste containers, do not cap containers for 24 hours after collecting the stripper residue and paint

chips.

*[3] Do not use this stripper on polysulfides. An example of a polysulfide is sealants.

*[4] Maximum of five paint stripping cycles are allowed during the life of the airplane.

*[5] Maximum of four paint stripping cycles are allowed during the life of the airplane.

*[6] Complete removal of organic materials by abrasive methods damages conversion coatings and may remove plating.

Strip conversion coatings and re-finish. Inspect plating (except chrome) for compliance with requirements and

supplementary chromate treatment requirements and re-finish as required.

*[7] This solution damages plating and conversion coating (for example, chemical conversion coating and anodized).

Rinse as soon as possible after stripping to stop etching. Plating and conversion coating exposed to the stripper shall

be stripped and refinished.

END OF TASK

4.

Ferrous Alloys - Paint Stripping

A. General

(1)

This task gives paint stripping instructions using the abrasive stripping methods that follow.

(a) Conventional Abrasive Blasting Method

(b) Plastic Media Blasting Method

(c) Wheat Starch Blasting Method

(d) Nanocomposite Blasting Method

(2) For metal surfaces, you can remove paint by abrasive stripping, or by brush-on or paint-on with

paint strippers or solvents. For procedures to remove paint with paint strippers or solvents, see

Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-150-801.

(3) Make sure that the areas that follow are covered.

(a) Lubricated parts

(b) Rubber parts

(c) Laminated plastic surfaces or parts

(d) Fiberglass surfaces or parts

(e) Aerodynamic smoothers

(f) Metal bonded parts

(g) Composite parts

(h) Adjacent access doors, fairings, and wing leading and trailing edges

(i) All areas adjacent to the area being stripped

(j) Drain holes and vents

(k) Pitot static probes and ports

(l) Angle-of-attack vanes

(m) Cargo door and entry door hinges and thresholds

(n) Cooling air exhaust duct

(o) Tires

(p) Ram air inlets

(q) Engines and the APU inlets and exhausts

(r) Pressurized drain valves

(s) Joints

(4) Make sure that the ambient temperature is between 50°F (10°C) and 100°F (38°C)..

NOTE: Do not use the stripping procedure in hot or wet weather.

C. Prepare to Strip the Surface

SUBTASK 51-21-11-150-007

(1) Prepare to strip the surface, do this task: Prepare for Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-370-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-110-003

(2) Clean the surface.

(a) Remove loose soil, excess grease, hydraulic fluid, oil, and metal shavings using a cotton

wiper, G00034.

\1) Use an oil absorbing wiper to remove oil, if necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034 or brush, G00215 wet with a Series 80

solvent, B50268.

(c) Immediately wipe the solvent from the surface using a clean, dry cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(d) Clean the surface again until the surface is free from all soil, excess grease, hydraulic

fluid, oil, and metal shavings.

D. Paint Stripping - Conventional Abrasive Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-011

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-110-004

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-001

(3) Abrasive blast the area to be stripped with apricot pit shell abrasive, G50823 or walnut shells

abrasive, G50822.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 90 psig (621 kPa) to 100 psig (689 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-002

(4) Clean the surface using clean, compressed air.

E. Paint Stripping - Plastic Media Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-012

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

737-600/700/800/900

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-11

NoC

Page 726

D633A101-BPA

Feb 15/2023

ECCN 9E991 BOEING PROPRIETARY - See title page for details

EFFECTIVITY

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryedSUBTASK 51-21-11-160-003

(2)

Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-002

(3) Plastic media blast using plastic media, E50011, Type V, Grade A to strip the paint.

(a) Screen the plastic media, E50011 to remove undersized media and contaminants.

NOTE: Examples of contaminants are paint flakes, metallic particles, and degraded

media.

(b)

Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 20 psig (138 kPa) to 40 psig (276 kPa).

(c) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) or more away from the

surface.

(d) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is at 45° to the surface.

(e) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-004

F. Paint Stripping - Wheat Starch Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-013

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-005

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-003

(3) Strip the surface using EnviroStrip 12/30 wheat starch media, E50010.

NOTE: Complete removal of organic coatings by wheat starch media blasting can damage

surface treatments on the base metal (for example: chemical conversion coating and

anodized coating) and may remove plating.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is between 30 psig (207 kPa) and 50 psig

(345 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Make sure that the nozzle angle is 20° to 60° from the surface.

(d) If the conversion coating was damaged, remove the remaining coating and reapply, as

necessary.

(e) If the plating was removed, inspect the plating.

\1) Make sure that the plating meets the requirements and re-finish, as necessary.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-006

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

(b) Wheat Starch Blasting Method

(c) Nanocomposite Blasting Method

(2) For metal surfaces, you can remove paint by abrasive stripping, or by brush-on or paint-on with

paint strippers or solvents. For procedures to remove paint with paint strippers or solvents, see

Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-150-801.

(3) Make sure that the areas that follow are covered.

(a) Lubricated parts

(b) Rubber parts

(c) Laminated plastic surfaces or parts

(d) Fiberglass surfaces or parts

(e) Aerodynamic smoothers

(f) Metal bonded parts

(g) Composite parts

(h) Adjacent access doors, fairings, and wing leading and trailing edges

(i) All areas adjacent to the area being stripped

(j) Drain holes and vents

(k) Pitot static probes and ports

(l) Angle-of-attack vanes

(m) Cargo door and entry door hinges and thresholds

(n) Cooling air exhaust duct

(o) Tires

(p) Ram air inlets

(q) Engines and the APU inlets and exhausts

(r) Pressurized drain valves

(s) Joints

(4) Make sure that the ambient temperature is between 50°F (10°C) and 100°F (38°C).

NOTE: Do not use the stripping procedure in hot or wet weather.

C. Prepare to Strip the Surface

SUBTASK 51-21-11-150-011

(1) Prepare to strip the surface, do this task: Prepare for Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-370-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-032

(2) Clean the surface.

(a) Remove loose soil, excess grease, hydraulic fluid, oil, and metal shavings using a cotton

wiper, G00034.

\1) Use an oil absorbing wiper to remove oil, if necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034 or brush, G00215 wet with a Series 80

solvent, B50268.

(c) Immediately wipe the solvent from the surface using a clean, dry cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(d) Clean the surface again until the surface is free from all soil, excess grease, hydraulic

fluid, oil, and metal shavings.

D. Paint Stripping - Plastic Media Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-025

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-033

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-040

(3) Plastic media blast using plastic media, E50011, Type V, Grade A to strip the paint.

(a) Screen the plastic media, E50011 to remove undersized media and contaminants.

NOTE: Examples of contaminants are paint flakes, metallic particles, and degraded

media.

(b)

Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 20 psig (138 kPa) to 40 psig (276 kPa).

(c) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) or more away from the

surface.

(d) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is at 45° to the surface.

(e) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

(4)

Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

E. Paint Stripping - Wheat Starch Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-026

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-035

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-041

(3) Strip the surface using EnviroStrip 12/30 wheat starch media, E50010.

NOTE: Complete removal of organic coatings by wheat starch media blasting can damage

surface treatments on the base metal (for example: chemical conversion coating and

anodized coating) and may remove plating.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is between 30 psig (207 kPa) and 50 psig

(345 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Make sure that the nozzle angle is 20° to 60° from the surface.

(d) If the conversion coating was damaged, remove the remaining coating and reapply, as

necessary.

(e) If the plating was removed, inspect the plating.

\1) Make sure that the plating meets the requirements and re-finish, as necessary.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-036

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

F. Paint Stripping - Nanocomposite Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-027

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-037

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-042

(3) Strip the surface using one of the nanocomposite abrasives that follow.

(a) For general purpose stripping, use Magic 1 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 30/60 Mesh.

(b) For an increased strip rate, use Magic II Composite Blast Media, E50012.

(c) To remove cured sealant, use Magic 3 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 10/60 Mesh.

(d) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is less than 32 psig (221 kPa).

(e) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(f) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is 40° to 60° to the surface.

TASK 51-21-11-150-810

12.

Aluminum Alloys - Paint Stripping

A. General

(1)

This task gives paint stripping instructions using the abrasive stripping methods that follow.

(a) Plastic Media Blasting Method

\1) This method is applicable to non-clad (bare) aluminum alloys with a gage thickness

of 0.125 in. (3.175 mm).

(b) Wheat Starch Blasting Method

\1) This method is applicable to the following.

a) Aluminum alloys with a gage thickness of 0.032 in. (0.813 mm) or greater,

including both clad and non-clad (bare) alloys.

b) Bonded honeycomb sandwich parts with aluminum facesheets 0.012 in.

(0.305 mm) thick or greater.

(c) Nanocomposite Blasting Method

\1) This method is applicable to the following.

a) Aluminum alloys with a gage thickness of 0.040 in. (1.016 mm) or greater.

b) Bonded honeycomb sandwich parts with aluminum facesheets 0.012 in.

(0.305 mm) thick or greater.

(2) For metal surfaces, you can remove paint by abrasive stripping, or by brush-on or paint-on with

paint strippers or solvents. For procedures to remove paint, with paint strippers or solvents,

see Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-150-801.

(a) Abrasions and scratches are satisfactory if a fingernail does not catch while pulled across

the abrasion or scratch, and the abrasion or scratch is not less than 0.10 in. (0.25 cm)

from a lap joint.

\1) It is not necessary to do supplemental inspections or to record the location of the

damage.

(b) If the abrasion or scratch catches the fingernail at the two worst areas, make sure that

the clad exists. If the clad exists, it is not required to do additional inspection or to record

the location of the damage.

(c) If the abrasion or scratch is not satisfactory, then refer to the SRM for instruction.

(3) Make sure that the areas that follow are covered.

(a) Lubricated parts

(b) Rubber parts

(c) Laminated plastic surfaces or parts

(d) Fiberglass surfaces or parts

(e) Aerodynamic smoothers

(f) Metal bonded parts

(g) Composite parts

(h) Adjacent access doors, fairings, and wing leading and trailing edges

C. Prepare to Strip the Surface

SUBTASK 51-21-11-150-015

(1) Prepare to strip the surface, do this task: Prepare for Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-370-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-056

(2) Clean the surface.

(a) Remove loose soil, excess grease, hydraulic fluid, oil, and metal shavings using a cotton

wiper, G00034.

\1) Use an oil absorbing wiper to remove oil, if necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034 or brush, G00215 wet with a Series 80

solvent, B50268.

(c) Immediately wipe the solvent from the surface using a clean, dry cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(d) Clean the surface again until the surface is free from all soil, excess grease, hydraulic

fluid, oil, and metal shavings.

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryedD. Paint Stripping - Plastic Media Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-035

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-057

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-022

(3) Plastic media blast using plastic media, E50011, Type V, Grade A to strip the paint.

(a) Screen the plastic media, E50011 to remove undersized media and contaminants.

NOTE: Examples of contaminants are paint flakes, metallic particles, and degraded

media.

(b)

Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 20 psig (138 kPa) to 40 psig (276 kPa).

(c) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) or more away from the

surface.

(d) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is at 45° to the surface.

(e) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-058

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

E. Paint Stripping - Wheat Starch Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-036

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-059

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-023

(3) Strip the surface using EnviroStrip 12/30 wheat starch media, E50010.

NOTE: Complete removal of organic coatings by wheat starch media blasting can damage

surface treatments on the base metal (for example: chemical conversion coating and

anodized coating) and may remove plating.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is between 30 psig (207 kPa) and 50 psig

(345 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Make sure that the nozzle angle is 20° to 60° from the surface.

(d) If the conversion coating was damaged, remove the remaining coating and reapply, as

necessary.

(e) If the plating was removed, inspect the plating.

\1) Make sure that the plating meets the requirements and re-finish, as necessary.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-060

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-078

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-031

(3) Plastic media blast using plastic media, E50011, Type V, Grade A to strip the paint.

(a) Screen the plastic media, E50011 to remove undersized media and contaminants.

NOTE: Examples of contaminants are paint flakes, metallic particles, and degraded

media.

(b)

Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 20 psig (138 kPa) to 40 psig (276 kPa).

(c) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) or more away from the

surface.

(d) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is at 45° to the surface.

(e) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-079

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

E. Paint Stripping - Wheat Starch Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-045

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-080

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-032

(3) Strip the surface using EnviroStrip 12/30 wheat starch media, E50010.

NOTE: Complete removal of organic coatings by wheat starch media blasting can damage

surface treatments on the base metal (for example: chemical conversion coating and

anodized coating) and may remove plating.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is between 30 psig (207 kPa) and 50 psig

(345 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Make sure that the nozzle angle is 20° to 60° from the surface.

(d) If the conversion coating was damaged, remove the remaining coating and reapply, as

necessary.

(e) If the plating was removed, inspect the plating.

\1) Make sure that the plating meets the requirements and re-finish, as necessary.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-081

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

F. Paint Stripping - Nanocomposite Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-046

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-082

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-033

(3) Strip the surface using one of the nanocomposite abrasives that follow.

(a) For general purpose stripping, use Magic 1 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 30/60 Mesh.

(b) For an increased strip rate, use Magic II Composite Blast Media, E50012.

(c) To remove cured sealant, use Magic 3 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 10/60 Mesh.

(d) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is less than 32 psig (221 kPa).

(g) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-083

C. Prepare to Strip the Surface

SUBTASK 51-21-11-150-020

(1) Prepare to strip the surface, do this task: Prepare for Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-370-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-091

(2) Clean the surface.

(a) Remove loose soil, excess grease, hydraulic fluid, oil, and metal shavings using a cotton

wiper, G00034.

\1) Use an oil absorbing wiper to remove oil, if necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034 or brush, G00215 wet with a Series 80

solvent, B50268.

(c) Immediately wipe the solvent from the surface using a clean, dry cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(d) Clean the surface again until the surface is free from all soil, excess grease, hydraulic

fluid, oil, and metal shavings.

D. Paint Stripping - Conventional Abrasive Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-050

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-092

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-037

(3) Abrade the area to be stripped with 150 grit abrasive paper, G02428 or finer.

(a) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-038

(4) Abrade the area to be stripped with 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077.

(a) Make sure that you feather the primer and topcoat.

(b) Make sure that you do not damage the fibers of the composite surface.

(c) If the surface has conductive coating, do the steps that follow.

\1) Remove all of the conductive coating.

NOTE: This is to obtain uniform conductivity after re-application.

\2) Re-apply the conductive coating.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-093

(5) Clean the surface using clean, compressed air.

E. Paint Stripping - Wheat Starch Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-051

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

A. This procedure has these tasks:

(1)

Prepare for Paint Stripping

(2) Paint Stripping

(3) Ferrous Alloys - Paint Stripping

(4) Titanium - Paint Stripping

(5) Titanium Alloys - Paint Stripping

(6) Titanium-Cadmium - Paint Stripping

(7) Nickel - Paint Stripping

(8) Nickel Alloys - Paint Stripping

(9) Magnesium Alloys - Paint Stripping

(10) Magnesium - Paint Stripping

(11) Aluminum Alloys - Paint Stripping

(12) Cadmium - Paint Stripping

(13) Zinc-Nickel - Paint Stripping

(14) Chromium - Paint Stripping

(15) Copper-Plating - Paint Stripping

(16) Composite Parts - Paint Stripping

B. Paint strippers or solvents are used to remove small quantities of paint on metal surfaces. Do not

use paint stripper on plastic laminations, fiberglass, aerodynamic smoother, edges of metal bonds,

or rubber parts. Use only approved solvents for these materials.

CAUTION

DO NOT USE PAINT STRIPPER ON COMPOSITE MATERIALS. PAINT

STRIPPERS CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE STRUCTURE OF THE PART.

(1) Use dry abrasive methods to remove the paint from the composite surfaces.

(a) For composites, the recommended abrasive is No. 240 Scotch-Brite. Use of alternative

blasting procedures for finish removal is structurally satisfactory. The procedure must

agree with the requirements given in SAE MA4872, “Paint Stripping of Commercial

Aircraft - Evaluation of Materials and Processes”. Refer to SOPM 20-30-02, or BAC5725,

“Stripping Organic Materials” for more information on paint stripping with blast media.

TASK 51-21-11-370-801

2. Prepare for Paint Stripping

A. General

(1)

The purpose of alkaline cleaning is to prepare the painted surfaces of the aircraft for paint

stripping. Paint strippers can be more effective if the aircraft surface is cleaned prior to paint

stripping.

E. Prepare for Paint Stripping

SUBTASK 51-21-11-580-001

(1) Ground the airplane (AIRPLANE GROUNDING - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES,

PAGEBLOCK 20-40-11/201).

SUBTASK 51-21-11-020-001

(2) Remove windshield wipers, as required.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-002

(3) Apply Scotch Flatback Masking Tape 250, G00270 to areas that you will not strip, or to areas

that can be damaged easily by the paint strippers.

(a) Pitot static probes and ports.

\1) Attach a “PITOT PROBES COVERED” tag, G02447 and “STATIC PORTS

COVERED” tag, G02444 to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

(b) Total air temperature (TAT) probe.

(c) Cooling air exhaust duct.

(d) Windshield wiper mounts.

(e) Cargo door and entry door hinges and thresholds.

(f) Mask all gaps containing mechanical (silicone rubber) seals.

NOTE: This is to prevent seal degradation.

(g) Mask unsealed Section 48 seams and other open joints that cannot be thoroughly rinsed.

(h)

Put the applicable tape or covers on lubricated parts, rubber parts, laminated plastics,

fiberglass, aerodynamic smoother, and metal-bonded edges.

(i) Apply tape a minimum of 1 in. (25 mm) wide on the skin to all access doors, fairings, wing

leading edges and trailing edges.

(j) Apply tape on the drain holes and vents.

(k) Apply tape on the pressurized drain valves.

(l) Acrylic parts.

(m) Glass parts.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-052

(4) If you will use restricted strippers (Table 701), do the steps that follow.

(a) Mask beyond the areas of sealant that follow.

NOTE: This is to prevent penetration to the joint.

\1) Lap joint sealant.

\1) Apply a second layer of aluminum tape that is offset from the initial application of

tape by 50%.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-840-001

(5) Install the (AOA) sensor angle of attack vane cover, COM-2499 (recommended) or AOA vane

protective cover, SPL-14189 (alternate).

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-053

(6) Mask the angle-of-attack (AOA) sensors.

(a) Attach a red tag with wire to the left control wheel in the flight deck.

\1) Write “AOA SENSORS COVERED” on the tag.

(b) Cover the angle-of-attack sensors with PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape.

\1) Apply PG-777 over the blade, plate, and blade-to-plate gap (Figure 703).

NOTE: This is to allow easier removal of 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape, G00291.

\2) Cover the PG-777 solvent-resistant masking tape with 3M 425 Aluminum Foil Tape,

G00291.

a)

Shingle the aluminum foil tape from the blade-to-plate gap up to the blade tip

until all of the masking tape is covered.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-054

(7) Put applicable plastic coated paper, G00365 covers on areas which are easily damaged by

strippers.

NOTE: You can use equivalent plastic sheeting that is resistant to paint strippers.

(a) Use the applicable material below to protect the surface.

\1)

Paper masking tape.

\2) Plastic-coated paper.

\3) Plastic sheeting.

\4) Wrapping paper, chemically neutral.

(b) Cover the areas that follow with the applicable cover.

\1) Wings.

a) Put the flaps in the full up position (Retract the Trailing Edge Flaps,

TASK 27-51-00-860-804, Leading Edge Flaps and Slats Retraction,

TASK 27-81-00-860-804).

\2) Tires.

\3) Engine and APU inlets and exhaust.

\4) Ram air inlets.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-003

(8) Cover the passenger and flight deck windows with the steps that follow (Figure 702).

(a) Use Protex 10VS tape, G50394, Protex 20V tape, G00139, pre-cut plastic adhesive

window mask paper (8216-2L), or Polyethylene-coated Kraft paper.

\1) Make sure that the polyethylene-coated Kraft paper is at least 0.001 in. (0.025 mm)

thick.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-096

(12) Do the steps that follow to clean the area.

(a) Remove the loose dirt, grease, and oil with MIL-PRF-680 degreasing solvent, B00074 or

aliphatic naphtha solvent, B00083.

NOTE: Be careful to not put solvent on a larger area than it is necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034, paint brush, STD-1080, or a sponge,

G00116 that is moist with MIL-PRF-680 degreasing solvent, B00074 or aliphatic naphtha

solvent, B00083.

\1) Rub the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034.

(c) Remove all unwanted solvent.

(d) Let the surface dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-097

(13) Do the steps that follow to clean the surface again.

(a) Use a spray bottle to apply the aliphatic naphtha solvent, B00083 on the surface.

(b) Clean the surface with a clean cotton wiper, G00034 until you remove all large pieces of

soil.

\1) Use a soft bristle brush, G00215 to clean the surface, if it is necessary.

(c) Clean the surface again with a new cotton wiper, G00034 until you can see no signs of

soil on the cheesecloth.

NOTE: It will be necessary to change the cheesecloth frequently when you clean the

surface.

(d)

Dry the area with a clean cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that you do not let drops of solvent dry on the surface.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-580-002

(14) Dry the aircraft.

(a) If actuator components or bearings were cleaned, lubricate those components as

necessary.

\1) Make sure to lubricate the actuator components or bearings outside the paint

hangar.

NOTE: This is to avoid paint contamination.

END OF TASK

3.

Paint Stripping

A. General

(1)

This task has the following steps:

(a) Brush-on or paint-on paint stripping

(b) A removal of the epoxy adhesives and adhesive primers

(c) A removal of the rain erosion coating from fiberglass

(d) Selection of paint strippers.

CAUTION

DO NOT LET PAINT STRIPPERS TOUCH FIBREGLASS, ACRYLIC WINDOWS,

SEALANT FILLETS, TEFLON LINED SELF-LUBRICATED BEARINGS,

ELECTRICAL TERMINAL PLUGS, NYLON COATED WIRES AND NYLON

BUSHINGS. THE CHEMICAL COMPOUNDS IN THE PAINT STRIPPERS WILL

CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE COMPONENTS.

(2) Before you clean, you must protect the surfaces and parts which are easily damaged by paint

strippers.

(a) Make sure that the paint strippers do not fall on the joints.

(b) Do not use paint strippers in the fuel tanks.

(3) Before you remove the paint with the stripping procedure, make sure that the surface is clean

and dry.

(a) Make sure that the ambient temperature is between 50°F (10°C) and 100°F (38°C).

\1) Do not use the stripping procedure in hot or wet weather.

(b) Make sure that the paint stripping equipment are fully clean of chemical residue.

NOTE: Refer to equipment manufacturer’s instructions to clean paint stripping

equipment.

CAUTION

DO NOT USE PAINT STRIPPER ON COMPOSITE MATERIALS. PAINT

STRIPPERS CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE STRUCTURE OF THE PART.

(4) Brush-on or spray-on stripping methods with paint strippers or solvents can be used on metal

surfaces.

(a) You can use a pressure sprayer gun, STD-447, or a brush to apply the paint strippers.

\1) The brush-on procedure is frequently used for line maintenance.

CAUTION

DO NOT USE THE SAME PUMPS AND HOSES WHEN MIXING DRUMS

OF DIFFERENT PAINT STRIPPERS THROUGH RECIRCULATION.

MIXING AND CROSS-CONTAMINATION CAN BE HIGHLY CORROSIVE

TO METAL SURFACES. THIS CAN CAUSE SKIN PITTING DAMAGE.

(b) Make sure that the components in the paint stripper are fully mixed.

\1) Do not use the same pumps and hoses when drums of different paint strippers are

mixed through recirculation.

a) Use dedicated pump and hose for different paint stripper type when drums of

paint striper are mixed through recirculation.

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryed2) Keep the container of paint stripper fully closed when it is not being used.

CAUTION

DO NOT APPLY ACID-ACTIVATED STRIPPER ONTO ANY AIRPLANE

SURFACE THAT HAS NOT HAD THE PEROXIDE-ACTIVATED STRIPPER

COMPLETELY AND THOROUGHLY RINSED OFF WITH WATER AND

VICE-VERSA. IF YOU MIX AND CROSS-CONTAMINATE, IT CAN BE

HIGHLY CORROSIVE TO METAL SURFACES. THIS CAN CAUSE SKIN

PITTING DAMAGE.

(c) Do not mix strippers of different manufacturers.

\1) Make sure that airplane is completely and thoroughly rinsed down with water to

remove all residue of the initial paint stripper when using different paint stripper.

\2) Do not apply acid-activated stripper onto any airplane surface that has not had the

peroxide-activated stripper completely and thoroughly rinsed off with water and

vise-versa.

NOTE: If necessary, a mild alkaline cleaner solution can be used to neutralize the

hydrogen-peroxide paint based stripper. You can use Super Bee 300LF

cleaner, B50394 [CP2615] or other equivalent cleaners approved for aircraft

exteriors to remove paint and stripper residue.

(d) Strippers that you apply with a brush or with a spray gun contain agents that make a

solution thick.

\1) Apply these strippers on the vertical and horizontal surfaces.

(e) Strippers that you apply with a cloth are used to remove temporary finishes, waxes, and

oversprays.

(f) Boeing specifications BAC5725 and BAC5771 provide procedures for paint stripping.

(g) Restricted strippers are not compatible with high-strength steel and magnesium. When

you use restricted strippers, make sure that all high-strength steel and magnesium parts

are masked.

(h) Acid strippers will discolor clad aluminum.

(i) You can usually use a solvent to remove small quantities of paint.

(j) Do not use paint strippers on the surfaces that follow:

NOTE: Only use approved solvents on these materials.

\1) Plastic laminates

\2)

Fiberglass

\3) Aerodynamic smoother

\4) Edges of metal bonds

\5) Rubber parts

\6) Lubricated parts

\7) Composite surfaces or parts.

(5) Abrasive stripping methods can be used on the surfaces that follow:

(a) Ferrous Alloys

(b) Titanium

(c) Titanium Alloys

(d) Titanium-Cadmium

WARNING

MANY ORGANIC FINISH STRIPPERS ARE FLAMMABLE, TOXIC OR

SAFETY PROCEDURES FOR SAFE OPERATION. AVOID PROLONGED OR

REPEATED BREATHING OF THE STRIPPER AND SOLVENT VAPORS. WEAR

AND SEEK MEDICAL ATTENTION.

(2) Do the paint stripping.

NOTE: Strip only an area that can be worked at one time.

(a) Refer to Table 701 for the approved stripping materials.

(b)

Make sure that you double-strip windows.

CAUTION

DO NOT APPLY ACID-ACTIVATED STRIPPER ONTO ANY AIRPLANE

SURFACE THAT HAS NOT HAD THE PEROXIDE-ACTIVATED STRIPPER

COMPLETELY AND THOROUGHLY RINSED OFF WITH WATER AND

VICE-VERSA. IF YOU MIX AND CROSS-CONTAMINATE, IT CAN BE

HIGHLY CORROSIVE TO METAL SURFACES. THIS CAN CAUSE SKIN

PITTING DAMAGE.

(c) Fully mix the strippers.

NOTE: Refer to the manufacturer’s instructions to mix the paint stripper.

\1) Make sure that airplane is completely and thoroughly rinsed down with water to

remove all residue of the initial paint stripper when using a different paint stripper.

\2) Do not apply acid-activated stripper onto any airplane surface that has not had the

peroxide-activated stripper completely and thoroughly rinsed off with water and

vise-versa.

NOTE: If necessary, a mild alkaline cleaner solution can be used to neutralize the

hydrogen-peroxide paint based stripper. You can use Super Bee 300LF

cleaner, B50394 [CP2615] or other equivalent cleaners approved for aircraft

exteriors to remove paint and stripper residue.

(d) Apply large quantities of the stripper on the paint.

NOTE: Keep the surface wet with the stripper.

\1) Put the stripper on with a natural bristle paint brush, STD-1080, or a non-atomizing

spray.

\2) If it is necessary, add more layers of the stripper.

(e) Let the stripper stay on the surface a sufficient time for the finish to become soft and

become wrinkled.

50°F (10°C) to 80°F (27°C)

*[1] Mixing or cross-contamination of acid-activated strippers with hydrogen peroxide-activated strippers can be highly

corrosive to metal surfaces. Before applying any paint strippers, special attention must be taken to:

\1) Thoroughly clean paint stripping equipment (spray guns, pots, pumps, pressure hoses, etc.) of any chemical

residue from prior usage per equipment manufacturer’s instructions. It is recommended to recirculate water through

the pump, hose, and spray gun at least 5X the volume of the hose and pump. After recirculation, check the pH of the

rinsate to verify it is the same pH as the water source. Scrub clean ID of pump/hose/gun from any material buildup

and thoroughly clean OD of spray gun. Clean squeegees and all tools contacting airplane surface.

\2) Ensure stripper is homogeneous by agitating material for a minimum of 30 minutes** (e.g with a drum roller or

recirculating material with cleaned pump/hose/gun). **this depends on if using a 55 gal drum or a large tote.

\3) Prior to applying stripper to the airplane, it is recommended to apply stripper from each lot (agitiated per step 2) to

abraded 2024-T3 clad panels. Allow the stripper to dwell and wipe off stripper at 4 and 8 hours. Use various sources

of lighting and magnification to inspect the panel for pitting. This is intended to identify any issues with stripper

material or equipment contamination prior to stripping the aircraft.

\4) If one type of paint stripper (e.g. peroxide-activated) is used on an aircraft and it is determined that a different type

of stripper is required (e.g. acid-activated), then the aircraft must be completely and thoroughly rinsed down with

water to remove all residue of the initial paint stripper. Do not apply acid-activated stripper onto any aircraft surface

that has not had the peroxide-activated stripper completely and thoroughly rinsed off with water.

*[2] Do not allow these peroxide-based strippers to come in contact directly with unpainted steel alloys. A thin layer of

these paint strippers can cause corrosion. In using these strippers, expose paint chips and spent strippers to a fine

spray of soap during clean-up after stripping, or rinse paint chips with water to remove paint stripper prior to

packaging in vented containers before disposal. Dispense the stripper through plastic or stainless steel equipment.

Collecting wastes in rusty drums, mixing conversion coating rise water with stripper residues, or throwing rags,

gloves, or other fabrics into the waste drum may cause combustion. Used material contaminated with paint flakes and

organic materials may undergo spontaneous pressurization. The paint stripper produces water and oxygen during the

paint removal process. This process will continue after the stripper is removed form the aircraft. To prevent pressure

from building up in waste containers, do not cap containers for 24 hours after collecting the stripper residue and paint

chips.

*[3] Do not use this stripper on polysulfides. An example of a polysulfide is sealants.

*[4] Maximum of five paint stripping cycles are allowed during the life of the airplane.

*[5] Maximum of four paint stripping cycles are allowed during the life of the airplane.

*[6] Complete removal of organic materials by abrasive methods damages conversion coatings and may remove plating.

Strip conversion coatings and re-finish. Inspect plating (except chrome) for compliance with requirements and

supplementary chromate treatment requirements and re-finish as required.

*[7] This solution damages plating and conversion coating (for example, chemical conversion coating and anodized).

Rinse as soon as possible after stripping to stop etching. Plating and conversion coating exposed to the stripper shall

be stripped and refinished.

END OF TASK

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryedTASK 51-21-11-150-802

4.

Ferrous Alloys - Paint Stripping

A. General

(1)

This task gives paint stripping instructions using the abrasive stripping methods that follow.

(a) Conventional Abrasive Blasting Method

(b) Plastic Media Blasting Method

(c) Wheat Starch Blasting Method

(d) Nanocomposite Blasting Method

(2) For metal surfaces, you can remove paint by abrasive stripping, or by brush-on or paint-on with

paint strippers or solvents. For procedures to remove paint with paint strippers or solvents, see

Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-150-801.

(3) Make sure that the areas that follow are covered.

(a) Lubricated parts

(b) Rubber parts

(c) Laminated plastic surfaces or parts

(d) Fiberglass surfaces or parts

(e) Aerodynamic smoothers

(f) Metal bonded parts

(g) Composite parts

(h) Adjacent access doors, fairings, and wing leading and trailing edges

(i) All areas adjacent to the area being stripped

(j) Drain holes and vents

(k) Pitot static probes and ports

(l) Angle-of-attack vanes

(m) Cargo door and entry door hinges and thresholds

(n) Cooling air exhaust duct

(o) Tires

(p) Ram air inlets

(q) Engines and the APU inlets and exhausts

(r) Pressurized drain valves

(s) Joints

(4) Make sure that the ambient temperature is between 50°F (10°C) and 100°F (38°C)..

NOTE: Do not use the stripping procedure in hot or wet weather.

C. Prepare to Strip the Surface

SUBTASK 51-21-11-150-007

(1) Prepare to strip the surface, do this task: Prepare for Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-370-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-110-003

(2) Clean the surface.

(a) Remove loose soil, excess grease, hydraulic fluid, oil, and metal shavings using a cotton

wiper, G00034.

\1) Use an oil absorbing wiper to remove oil, if necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034 or brush, G00215 wet with a Series 80

solvent, B50268.

(c) Immediately wipe the solvent from the surface using a clean, dry cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(d) Clean the surface again until the surface is free from all soil, excess grease, hydraulic

fluid, oil, and metal shavings.

D. Paint Stripping - Conventional Abrasive Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-011

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-110-004

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-001

(3) Abrasive blast the area to be stripped with apricot pit shell abrasive, G50823 or walnut shells

abrasive, G50822.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 90 psig (621 kPa) to 100 psig (689 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-002

(4) Clean the surface using clean, compressed air.

E. Paint Stripping - Plastic Media Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-012

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

737-600/700/800/900

AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE MANUAL

51-21-11

NoC

Page 726

D633A101-BPA

Feb 15/2023

ECCN 9E991 BOEING PROPRIETARY - See title page for details

EFFECTIVITY

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryedSUBTASK 51-21-11-160-003

(2)

Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-002

(3) Plastic media blast using plastic media, E50011, Type V, Grade A to strip the paint.

(a) Screen the plastic media, E50011 to remove undersized media and contaminants.

NOTE: Examples of contaminants are paint flakes, metallic particles, and degraded

media.

(b)

Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 20 psig (138 kPa) to 40 psig (276 kPa).

(c) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) or more away from the

surface.

(d) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is at 45° to the surface.

(e) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-004

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

F. Paint Stripping - Wheat Starch Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-013

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-005

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-003

(3) Strip the surface using EnviroStrip 12/30 wheat starch media, E50010.

NOTE: Complete removal of organic coatings by wheat starch media blasting can damage

surface treatments on the base metal (for example: chemical conversion coating and

anodized coating) and may remove plating.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is between 30 psig (207 kPa) and 50 psig

(345 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Make sure that the nozzle angle is 20° to 60° from the surface.

(d) If the conversion coating was damaged, remove the remaining coating and reapply, as

necessary.

(e) If the plating was removed, inspect the plating.

\1) Make sure that the plating meets the requirements and re-finish, as necessary.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-006

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Use an oil absorbing wiper to remove oil, if necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034 or brush, G00215 wet with a Series 80

solvent, B50268.

(c) Immediately wipe the solvent from the surface using a clean, dry cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(d) Clean the surface again until the surface is free from all soil, excess grease, hydraulic

fluid, oil, and metal shavings.

D. Paint Stripping - Plastic Media Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-022

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-026

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-012

(3) Plastic media blast using plastic media, E50011, Type V, Grade A to strip the paint.

(a) Screen the plastic media, E50011 to remove undersized media and contaminants.

NOTE: Examples of contaminants are paint flakes, metallic particles, and degraded

media.

(b)

Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 20 psig (138 kPa) to 40 psig (276 kPa).

(c) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) or more away from the

surface.

(d) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is at 45° to the surface.

(e) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-027

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryedE. Paint Stripping - Wheat Starch Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-023

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-028

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-013

(3) Strip the surface using EnviroStrip 12/30 wheat starch media, E50010.

NOTE: Complete removal of organic coatings by wheat starch media blasting can damage

surface treatments on the base metal (for example: chemical conversion coating and

anodized coating) and may remove plating.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is between 30 psig (207 kPa) and 50 psig

(345 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Make sure that the nozzle angle is 20° to 60° from the surface.

(d) If the conversion coating was damaged, remove the remaining coating and reapply, as

necessary.

(e) If the plating was removed, inspect the plating.

\1) Make sure that the plating meets the requirements and re-finish, as necessary.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-029

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

F. Paint Stripping - Nanocomposite Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-024

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-030

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-014

(3) Strip the surface using one of the nanocomposite abrasives that follow.

(a) For general purpose stripping, use Magic 1 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 30/60 Mesh.

(b) For an increased strip rate, use Magic II Composite Blast Media, E50012.

(c) To remove cured sealant, use Magic 3 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 10/60 Mesh.

(d) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is less than 32 psig (221 kPa).

(e) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(f) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is 40° to 60° to the surface.

(g) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-031

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

8.

Nickel - Paint Stripping

A. General

(1)

This task gives paint stripping instructions using the abrasive stripping methods that follow.

(a) Plastic Media Blasting Method

(b) Wheat Starch Blasting Method

(c) Nanocomposite Blasting Method

(2) For metal surfaces, you can remove paint by abrasive stripping, or by brush-on or paint-on with

paint strippers or solvents. For procedures to remove paint with paint strippers or solvents, see

Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-150-801.

(3) Make sure that the areas that follow are covered.

(a) Lubricated parts

(b) Rubber parts

(c) Laminated plastic surfaces or parts

(d) Fiberglass surfaces or parts

(e) Aerodynamic smoothers

(f) Metal bonded parts

(g) Composite parts

(h) Adjacent access doors, fairings, and wing leading and trailing edges

(i) All areas adjacent to the area being stripped

(j) Drain holes and vents

(k) Pitot static probes and ports

(l) Angle-of-attack vanes

(m) Cargo door and entry door hinges and thresholds

(n) Cooling air exhaust duct

(o) Tires

(p) Ram air inlets

(q) Engines and the APU inlets and exhausts

(r) Pressurized drain valves

(s) Joints

(4) Make sure that the ambient temperature is between 50°F (10°C) and 100°F (38°C).

NOTE: Do not use the stripping procedure in hot or wet weather.

\1) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(d) Clean the surface again until the surface is free from all soil, excess grease, hydraulic

fluid, oil, and metal shavings.

D. Paint Stripping - Plastic Media Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-032

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-050

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-019

(3) Plastic media blast using plastic media, E50011, Type V, Grade A to strip the paint.

(a) Screen the plastic media, E50011 to remove undersized media and contaminants.

NOTE: Examples of contaminants are paint flakes, metallic particles, and degraded

media.

(b)

Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 20 psig (138 kPa) to 40 psig (276 kPa).

(c) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) or more away from the

surface.

(d) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is at 45° to the surface.

(e) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-051

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-033

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-052

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-020

(3) Strip the surface using EnviroStrip 12/30 wheat starch media, E50010.

NOTE: Complete removal of organic coatings by wheat starch media blasting can damage

surface treatments on the base metal (for example: chemical conversion coating and

anodized coating) and may remove plating.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is between 30 psig (207 kPa) and 50 psig

(345 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Make sure that the nozzle angle is 20° to 60° from the surface.

(d) If the conversion coating was damaged, remove the remaining coating and reapply, as

necessary.

F. Paint Stripping - Nanocomposite Blasting Method

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

(3) Strip the surface using one of the nanocomposite abrasives that follow.

(a) For general purpose stripping, use Magic 1 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 30/60 Mesh.

(b) For an increased strip rate, use Magic II Composite Blast Media, E50012.

(c) To remove cured sealant, use Magic 3 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 10/60 Mesh.

(d) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is less than 32 psig (221 kPa).

(e) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(f) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is 40° to 60° to the surface.

(g) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-055

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

TASK 51-21-11-150-810

12.

Aluminum Alloys - Paint Stripping

A. General

(1)

This task gives paint stripping instructions using the abrasive stripping methods that follow.

(a) Plastic Media Blasting Method

\1) This method is applicable to non-clad (bare) aluminum alloys with a gage thickness

of 0.125 in. (3.175 mm).

(b) Wheat Starch Blasting Method

\1) This method is applicable to the following.

a) Aluminum alloys with a gage thickness of 0.032 in. (0.813 mm) or greater,

including both clad and non-clad (bare) alloys.

b) Bonded honeycomb sandwich parts with aluminum facesheets 0.012 in.

(0.305 mm) thick or greater.

(c) Nanocomposite Blasting Method

\1) This method is applicable to the following.

a) Aluminum alloys with a gage thickness of 0.040 in. (1.016 mm) or greater.

b) Bonded honeycomb sandwich parts with aluminum facesheets 0.012 in.

(0.305 mm) thick or greater.

(2) For metal surfaces, you can remove paint by abrasive stripping, or by brush-on or paint-on with

paint strippers or solvents. For procedures to remove paint, with paint strippers or solvents,

see Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-150-801.

(a) Abrasions and scratches are satisfactory if a fingernail does not catch while pulled across

the abrasion or scratch, and the abrasion or scratch is not less than 0.10 in. (0.25 cm)

from a lap joint.

\1) It is not necessary to do supplemental inspections or to record the location of the

damage.

(b) If the abrasion or scratch catches the fingernail at the two worst areas, make sure that

the clad exists. If the clad exists, it is not required to do additional inspection or to record

the location of the damage.

(c) If the abrasion or scratch is not satisfactory, then refer to the SRM for instruction.

(3) Make sure that the areas that follow are covered.

(a) Lubricated parts

(b) Rubber parts

(c) Laminated plastic surfaces or parts

(d) Fiberglass surfaces or parts

(e) Aerodynamic smoothers

(f) Metal bonded parts

(g) Composite parts

(h) Adjacent access doors, fairings, and wing leading and trailing edges

737-600/700/800/900

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-075

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-030

(3) Strip the surface using one of the nanocomposite abrasives that follow.

(a) For general purpose stripping, use Magic 1 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 30/60 Mesh.

(b) For an increased strip rate, use Magic II Composite Blast Media, E50012.

(c) To remove cured sealant, use Magic 3 Nanocomposite Abrasive Media, 10/60 Mesh.

(d) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is less than 32 psig (221 kPa).

(e) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(f) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is 40° to 60° to the surface.

(g) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-076

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034

END OF TASK

C. Prepare to Strip the Surface

SUBTASK 51-21-11-150-018

(1) Prepare to strip the surface, do this task: Prepare for Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-370-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-077

(2) Clean the surface.

(a) Remove loose soil, excess grease, hydraulic fluid, oil, and metal shavings using a cotton

wiper, G00034.

\1) Use an oil absorbing wiper to remove oil, if necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034 or brush, G00215 wet with a Series 80

solvent, B50268.

(c) Immediately wipe the solvent from the surface using a clean, dry cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

(d) Clean the surface again until the surface is free from all soil, excess grease, hydraulic

fluid, oil, and metal shavings.

BPA ALL

Valid until 7days after A/C N307FL is deliveryedD. Paint Stripping - Plastic Media Blasting Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-044

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-078

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-031

(3) Plastic media blast using plastic media, E50011, Type V, Grade A to strip the paint.

(a) Screen the plastic media, E50011 to remove undersized media and contaminants.

NOTE: Examples of contaminants are paint flakes, metallic particles, and degraded

media.

(b)

Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is 20 psig (138 kPa) to 40 psig (276 kPa).

(c) Make sure that the nozzle is approximately 6 in. (152 mm) or more away from the

surface.

(d) Make sure that the angle of the nozzle is at 45° to the surface.

(e) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-079

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

(b) Dry the surface with a clean, cotton wiper, G00034.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-080

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-032

(3) Strip the surface using EnviroStrip 12/30 wheat starch media, E50010.

NOTE: Complete removal of organic coatings by wheat starch media blasting can damage

surface treatments on the base metal (for example: chemical conversion coating and

anodized coating) and may remove plating.

(a) Make sure that the nozzle air pressure is between 30 psig (207 kPa) and 50 psig

(345 kPa).

(b) Make sure that the nozzle is at least 6 in. (152 mm) from the surface.

(c) Make sure that the nozzle angle is 20° to 60° from the surface.

(d) If the conversion coating was damaged, remove the remaining coating and reapply, as

necessary.

(e) If the plating was removed, inspect the plating.

\1) Make sure that the plating meets the requirements and re-finish, as necessary.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-081

(4) Clean the surface.

(a) Rinse the surface with water.

C. Prepare to Strip the Surface

SUBTASK 51-21-11-150-020

(1) Prepare to strip the surface, do this task: Prepare for Paint Stripping, TASK 51-21-11-370-801.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-091

(2) Clean the surface.

(a) Remove loose soil, excess grease, hydraulic fluid, oil, and metal shavings using a cotton

wiper, G00034.

\1) Use an oil absorbing wiper to remove oil, if necessary.

(b) Clean the surface with a cotton wiper, G00034 or brush, G00215 wet with a Series 80

solvent, B50268.

(c) Immediately wipe the solvent from the surface using a clean, dry cotton wiper, G00034.

\1) Make sure that the solvent does not dry on the surface.

fluid, oil, and metal shavings.

D. Paint Stripping - Conventional Abrasive Method

SUBTASK 51-21-11-950-050

(1) Make sure that the areas that will not be stripped are masked.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-092

(2) Make sure that the areas that will be stripped are clean and dry.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-037

(3) Abrade the area to be stripped with 150 grit abrasive paper, G02428 or finer.

(a) Abrade the surface equally down to the primer surface.

NOTE: It is not necessary to remove the primers for the reapplication of primer, enamels,

or topcoat.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-120-038

(4) Abrade the area to be stripped with 240 grit or finer abrasive paper, G50077.

(a) Make sure that you feather the primer and topcoat.

(b) Make sure that you do not damage the fibers of the composite surface.

(c) If the surface has conductive coating, do the steps that follow.

\1) Remove all of the conductive coating.

NOTE: This is to obtain uniform conductivity after re-application.

\2) Re-apply the conductive coating.

SUBTASK 51-21-11-160-093

(5) Clean the surface using clean, compressed air.

entry.title: AIRBUS章节号25-20-00
entry.content:
空客内饰翻新依据

TASK 25-20-00-370-001-A

Refurbishment of the Handrail, the Door and the Interior of the Overhead Stowage Compartment (OHSC)

WARNING:

BE CAREFUL WHEN YOU USE CONSUMABLE MATERIALS. OBEY THE MATERIAL MANUFACTURER’S INSTRUCTIONS AND YOUR LOCAL REGULATIONS.

CAUTION:

MAKE A RECORD OF THE REFURBISHMENT OF EACH COMPONENT TO MAKE SURE THAT THIS DATA IS AVAILABLE FOR SUBSEQUENT REFURBISHMENTS. THE REFURBISHMENT CAN HAVE AN EFFECT ON THE WEIGHT AND FLAMMABILITY PROPERTIES OF THE AIRCRAFT.

Reason for the Job

Self explanatory

Job Set-up Information

Job Set-up

SUBTASK 25-20-00-861-052-A

A.

Energization of the Electrical Network

(1)

Energize the ground service network

Ref. AMM TASK 24-42-00-861-001.

Procedure

SUBTASK 25-20-00-370-051-B

A.

Refurbishment of the OHSC Handrail

NOTE:

The OHSC handrail is made from a thermoplastic material, applied with a top coat.

NOTE:

The procedure is for the refurbishment of painted OHSC handrails only.

CAUTION:

MEASURE THE THICKNESS OF THE PAINT ON THE SURFACES OF THE COMPONENT BEFORE YOU PAINT THEM AGAIN. PAINT THAT IS TOO THICK INCREASES THE WEIGHT AND THE FLAMMABILITY PROPERTIES OF THE AIRCRAFT.

(1)

Obey the MAINTENANCE HISTORY DATA.

(2)

Remove the OHSC handrail Ref. AMM TASK 25-24-41-960-001.

(3)

Do a visual inspection of the OHSC handrail.

CAUTION:

MAKE SURE THAT THE TOP COAT LAYER IS DRY TO GET A CORRECT MEASUREMENT RESULT. ALL SPECIFIED TOP COAT LAYERS ARE TEXTURED. REFER TO THE MAXIMUM VALUE OF THE TOP COAT LAYER BECAUSE THE MAXIMUM VALUE IS APPLICABLE.

(4)

Use the GAGE-THICKNESS, PAINT BORER 518 and measure the thickness of the top coat layer.

CAUTION:

DO NOT CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE SURFACE OF THE THERMOPLASTIC MATERIAL WHEN YOU REMOVE THE PAINT COATING WITH ABRASIVE PAPER.

(5)

Make sure that the maximum thickness of the top coat layer is 65 micrometers:

-

If the maximum thickness of the top coat layer is more than 65 micrometers, use the CLOTH-EMERY (GRADE 320 - 400) and carefully remove the unwanted paint from the OHSC handrail.

-

If the maximum thickness of the top coat layer is less than 65 micrometers, use the CLOTH-EMERY (GRADE 320 - 400) and carefully make the surface rough.

(6)

Clean the surface with Non Aqueous Cleaner– Isopropyl Alcohol - (Material Ref. 08BBD1) and a Textile-Lint free Cotton - (Material Ref. 14SBA1).

(7)

Wait for a minimum of five minutes until the surface is dry.

(8)

Use the GUN - AIR SPRAY, STANDARD PAINT or the PAINTBRUSH and apply a layer of top coat Consumable material Alexit 346-55 or Consumable material Alexit 346-57 or Consumable material FR2/55 or Consumable material FR6/55 with a maximum thickness of 25 micrometers on the surface of the OHSC handrail.

NOTE:

The maximum permitted thickness of the top coat layer is 90 micrometers (textured).

(9)

Let the paint dry.

(10)

Install the OHSC handrail Ref. AMM TASK 25-24-41-960-001.

SUBTASK 25-20-00-370-052-B

B.

Refurbishment of the OHSC Door with a Paint Decor

NOTE:

The OHSC door is made of a phenolic honeycomb sandwich, with layers of a paint system (a pore filler and a top coat).

NOTE:

This procedure is for the refurbishment of painted OHSC doors only.

NOTE:

For the refurbishment of the OHSC doors with décor foil, there is a special procedure that includes the repair or replacement of the décor foil, Ref. AMM TASK 25-20-00-340-003.

CAUTION:

MEASURE THE THICKNESS OF THE PAINT ON THE SURFACES OF THE COMPONENT BEFORE YOU PAINT THEM AGAIN. PAINT THAT IS TOO THICK INCREASES THE WEIGHT AND THE FLAMMABILITY PROPERTIES OF THE AIRCRAFT.

(1)

Obey the MAINTENANCE HISTORY DATA.

(2)

Remove the OHSC door Ref. AMM TASK 25-24-41-000-002.

(3)

Do a visual inspection of the OHSC door.

CAUTION:

MAKE SURE THAT THE TOP COAT LAYER IS DRY TO GET A CORRECT MEASUREMENT RESULT. ALL SPECIFIED TOP COAT LAYERS ARE TEXTURED. REFER TO THE MAXIMUM VALUE OF THE TOP COAT LAYER BECAUSE THE MAXIMUM VALUE IS APPLICABLE.

(4)

Use the GAGE-THICKNESS, PAINT BORER 518 and measure the thickness of the top coat layer.

CAUTION:

DO NOT CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE SURFACE OF THE COMPOSITE MATERIAL WHEN YOU REMOVE THE PAINT COATING WITH ABRASIVE PAPER.

(5)

Make sure that the maximum thickness of the top coat layer is 65 micrometers:

-

If the maximum thickness of the top coat layer is more than 65 micrometers, use the CLOTH-EMERY (GRADE 320 - 400) and carefully remove the unwanted paint from the OHSC door.

-

If the maximum thickness of the top coat layer is less than 65 micrometers, use the CLOTH-EMERY (GRADE 320 - 400) and carefully make the surface rough.

(6)

Clean the surface with Non Aqueous Cleaner– Isopropyl Alcohol - (Material Ref. 08BBD1) and a Textile-Lint free Cotton - (Material Ref. 14SBA1).

(7)

Wait for a minimum of five minutes until the surface is dry.

(8)

Use the GUN - AIR SPRAY, STANDARD PAINT or the PAINTBRUSH and apply a layer of top coat Consumable material Alexit 346-55 or Consumable material Alexit 346-57 or Consumable material FR2/55 or Consumable material FR6/55 with a maximum thickness of 25 micrometers on the surface of the OHSC door.

NOTE:

The maximum permitted thickness of the top coat layer is 90 micrometers (textured).

(9)

Let the paint dry.

(10)

Install the OHSC door Ref. AMM TASK 25-24-41-400-002.

SUBTASK 25-20-00-370-053-B

C.

NOTE:

The OHSC interior is made of a phenolic honeycomb sandwich, with a thin white vinyl-foil and an optional thin layer of top coat.

-

If the maximum thickness of the top coat layer is less than 65 micrometers, use the CLOTH-EMERY (GRADE 320 - 400) and carefully make the surface rough.

(5)

Clean the surface with Non Aqueous Cleaner– Isopropyl Alcohol - (Material Ref. 08BBD1) and a Textile-Lint free Cotton - (Material Ref. 14SBA1).

(6)

Wait for a minimum of five minutes until the surface is dry.

(7)

Use the GUN - AIR SPRAY, STANDARD PAINT or the PAINTBRUSH and apply a layer of top coat Consumable material Alexit 346-55 or Consumable material Alexit 346-57 or Consumable material FR2/55 or Consumable material FR6/55 with a maximum thickness of 25 micrometers on the surface of the OHSC interior.

NOTE:

The maximum permitted thickness of the top coat layer is 90 micrometers (textured).

(8)

Let the paint dry.
